charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
pageSummary: Squat Squad because they're doing whatever it takes!
story:
Thanks for supporting our fundraiser for Macmillan.

BIE's Squat Squad are raising money for Macmillan by toning up their glutes and completing 100 squats per day for 30 days! In addition to raising funds for a very worthwhile cause, the Squat Squad are also excited to be fine tuning their derrieres in the lead up to summer...

Each member of the Squat Squad will be challenging themselves to complete 100 squats per day for 30 days.

Sound too easy, why not join us? Those scared of the squat can just sit back and laugh at the rest of us!

Macmillan give people with cancer everything they've got. If you're diagnosed, your worries are their worries. They're doing whatever it takes. But without your help they can't support everyone who needs them.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

story: Marie was a kind, strong, independent woman who will be remembered by us all through our lovely shared memories of her. She was a beautiful lady inside and out and she dealt with her illness as she dealt with her life with bravery and courage. She continued to think of others before herself right to the end. She will be greatly missed by her family who she cherished dearly, her friends and all who knew her.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
My amazing dad Roy passed away from stage 4 lung cancer on 18th February 2021 aged 76. 

He was diagnosed in late December 2020 and was looked after amazingly by the most lovely Macmillan Cancer Nurses named Nicky Walker & Jayne Powell at Walsall Manor Hospital. The compassion and care they showed to him was something else.  

Before my dad was diagnosed he was the healthiest 76 year old I’ve ever come across, looked 20 years younger and was fitter than me! My dad had only been in hospital once in his life before he had cancer and that was 7 years ago, he only stayed overnight. He hated hospitals just like me, so I am so grateful that both Nicky & Jayne made his visits so pleasant and where he felt comfortable and wasn’t anxious for his appointments if they are going to be there. . 

My Dad was a quiet man who kept himself to himself and didn’t ask for help from anyone. It comforts me to know that these two amazing women did all they could to put my dad at ease and visited him whilst he stayed in hospital which he said brightened up his day when he felt down. I know he was so grateful for both of them, so much so he looked forward to seeing them. 

So this is a small thank you for making the last few months of my dads life that little bit better, myself and my family are truly grateful. 

Chanice. X

pageSummary: I am offering free Salesforce training sessions because I want to raise money for MacMillan Cancer Support
pageSummaryWhat: I am offering free Salesforce training sessions
pageSummaryWhy: I want to raise money for MacMillan Cancer Support
story:
6 weeks ago, my beautiful 16 year old niece Jocelyn was diagnosed with Leukaemia. It was a complete shock for the whole family. She went through very difficult days waiting for test results and going through difficult treatments.

During these difficult days, the kindness and professionalism from the MacMillan team was exceptional.

Her treatment is still ongoing and will be for some time, but knowing that the MacMillan team is here, available with a very gentle and honest approach makes the whole difference day after day.

So just to say a massive thank you on behalf of the whole family, I have decided to start this fundraising.

In April: 

- I will offer free online salesforce discovery and training sessions running every Saturday in April: Please register here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/salesforce-discovery-tickets-144879645921

- I will also walk/run 10 000 steps a day, updates will be posted to this page.

Please donate whatever you can!

pageSummary: Crocheting Squarea because I want to raise as much money as possible!
pageSummaryWhy: I want to raise as much money as possible!
story:
I work for Toolstation. Over the next two years we will raising as much money as we can for Macmillan. This is a charity close to my heart. I lost my Gran 4 years ago to pancreatic cancer and the Macmillan nurses were always there for her. We still have family members fighting this awful disease today.

I want to do my part. I'll be crocheting a "Macmillan Square" for every £1 raised. Once my fundraiser has come to an end I will join all of our squares together to create blankets. I hope to raise even more money with these. 

My very first square is in memory of my Gran.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
For the past 4 years I have hosted an event called “Battle Cancer / Battle Rope Challenge”. 

As we we’re not allowed to hold any events last year we missed it. I don’t want to wait any longer to see if we will another year... so I’m just going to get on and do what I can by myself. 

I made a promise I would raise as much money and awareness as I could for this incredible charity. 

Before my family were given so much love and care from Macmillan I didn’t really know much of what they did. I’d like to help bring awareness to as many as possible.  

Please help by sponsoring me. Anything you can do to raise the awareness or money would be absolutely amazing. 💚💚

My challenge is to bear crawl around the lake that has been a massive part of the lock-down for me and others in our local area.

I have walked around it and listened to so many amazing people and their stories of how the pandemic has effected them. I swear it has healing powers. Or maybe it’s just nature itself. 💚💚

I can’t give a date as I’m not allowed to create an event or encourage a gathering. (It will be within the next few weeks 😁). I will go live on Facebook just a few minutes before I start so you can cheer me on virtually and watch me struggle. 

Thank you x


Alex

story: The lives of family members, close friends, and work colleagues have all been impacted by cancer, either directly or indirectly. I will be taking on the Macmillan Mighty Hike half marathon on 3rd July, walking 13 miles across the Yorkshire Dales dressed as Captain America and carrying his shield. I will be walking with Duncan Allen, Helen Anderson, Laura Stevens and Alex as Team Plant-Huggers.  We all work for the Department for environment, food and rural affairs (Defra) protecting the UK's plants and trees from exotic pests and diseases,  hence the team name. We have been set the ambitious goal of collectively raising £1,250. Any amount you could donate to help us reach this target would be gratefully received and go towards supporting Macmillan Cancer Support - a great charity. Thank you for all your support. Best Wishes The Plant-Huggers!

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising.

I will be running Edinburgh (virtual) Marathon in May 2021. Due to COVID, the event will not be taking place in it's usual format, so I will instead be tackling the 26.2 miles around Norwich.

I have decided to fundraise for Macmillan Cancer Support. My mum, Dawn, was diagnosed with metastatic renal cancer in 2015. Throughout her battle, the team at Macmillan were on hand to provide support to both her and my family. My mum always talked very fondly of Louise, her Macmillan Nurse, who was always there in what were certainly the toughest times. Sadly, my mum lost her battle with cancer in October 2018. I would love to give something back to the team at Macmillan to help them support others in their time of need.

Anything you can donate is greatly appreciated and will go to a charity providing an incredibly important service.

pageSummary: I am going to run the Brighton Half Marathon because the support and help they offer is truely amazing
pageSummaryWhat: I am going to run the Brighton Half Marathon
pageSummaryWhy: the support and help they offer is truely amazing
story: Cancer does not only impact the person being diagnosed. That diagnosis has a massive impact on that persons family and friends. At the end of 2020, my father was diagnosed with Colorectal cancer for which he has had to undergo operations and is currently having Chemotherapy. His battle is not his to fight alone; it is being fought every day by his family and friends around him - and it is a battle we will win.  The work of Macmillan Cancer Support has been nothing shy of amazing in the support, care and advice they can give, and it is an honour to be able to raise money for them. Every day, cancer patients face an enormous mental and physical battle, and over the course of their treatment undergo hardship and pain unimaginable to those without Cancer. In light of this, I will be running the Brighton Half Marathon in under 1 hour 30 minutes (a difficult challenge) so that I too can get a glimpse of the hardship that others have to endure every day. Cancer does not discriminate against age, gender or race - you never know if or when you, a family member or a friend might be diagnosed. If you can, please spare a penny, a pound or even ten pounds as it will help support the Charity that make the battle against Cancer that little bit easier and help swing the odds ever in your favour.

pageSummaryWhat: We are walking the 26 mile Giants Causeway
story:
Thank you for supporting our fundraising challenge hike of 26 miles for MacMillan Cancer Support. 

We are Bridin, Julia and Rosemary.

Our lives like many others in Northern Ireland  have been touched by cancer. In under taking this challenge we want to  raise awareness around cancer care , acknowledge the devastation caused by this disease and pay tribute to  the incredible Macmillan nurses who provide support and care to those who need it . By raising money through this challenge we can help to support this invaluable service and ensure MacMillan  nurses  are always available to help  when they are needed. 

At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
eventName: 1000 mile charity walk by London Fire Brigade Fire Engineering Group
story:
Fire Engineering Group are supporting an amazing cancer charity this March by undertaking a step challenge as a team. The charity they are supporting is McMillan cancer support.

Over the past year a number of the team have been directly impacted by cancer and recognise what a vital role some of these charities play in supporting both individuals and families. Lynsey’s dad was diagnosed with prostate cancer in March last year and her father in law with a cancer relapse in October; “Throughout my dad’s treatment he had regular sessions programmed in with the McMillan nurses who offered support and were happy to explain aspects of his treatment plan and anything else he wanted to ask about – I’m really grateful for the service that they offer people at what can be a really scary time and that this support has remained in place at a time when many have to face their treatment sessions alone due to the Covid restrictions in place at hospitals”

FEG are committing to get out and about every day in March and complete, collectively a total of 2,000,000 steps which equates roughly to 1000 miles. We’d appreciate any support you might be able to provide us – encouragement or, if possible, monetary donations which will go to help these amazing charities.

We’ll keep you updated on our progress and guess we’d better find some decent walking shoes…

eventName: 24 Hour Isle of Wight Coast Walk!
story:
We are all taking on the challenge of a 24 Hour Walk. The following group who are taking part in this 70 mile round trip of the Isle of Wight is: Sam Parnell, Shona Parnell, Billy Scott, Jim Scott, Spike Pearce and Tom Burr-Hersey. This will push us mentally and physically but we will do all it takes to complete it. Our main aim is to raise as much money as possibly for Macmillan: before, during and after the challenge... so any donations big or small are welcome. 

We are planning to do this on 24th September 2021.

Also, if you would like to sponsor or gift our walking kit or equipment for the challenge then please get in contact with any of the participants and we can organise this. 

Never, has any of us done anything like this before!

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
pageSummary: I am running the 4/4/48 challenge because everyone deserves to be supported through cancer
pageSummaryWhy: everyone deserves to be supported through cancer
story:
Thank you for taking time to read my page  - We're back with another mad challenge to raise money for Macmillan Cancer, a charity near and dear to my family and many others. 

This year I will be attempting to complete the 4/4/48 challenge, inspired by retired Navy seal, David Goggins in May (exact date TBC). This challenge involves running 4 miles, every 4 hours for 48 hours...This will total 48 miles in 2 days with intermittent sleep and little recovery time between runs. This is a challenge beyond my comfort zone, but thats what makes it a challenge right?!

I will be running to raise money for Macmillan Cancer support. During the pandemic, many cancer patients have struggled with cancelled appointments/treatments, delayed operations which are potentially life threatening and increased anxiety surrounding their physical, mental and financial well being. Macmillan provide expert services to support those living with cancer and their loved ones, and the demand of their services has increased throughout the pandemic. 

As always, I will being do this challenge in memory on my mum. I will forever be grateful for the support she received from Macmillan, and I hope by raising money, this will allow that support to continue for those in similar positions.

Any donations of any size, will be greatly appreciated and go towards a great cause, and if you fancy a 4 miles shift (location London) ,the company will be very appreciated!

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Steve passed away on 8th March with terminal lung cancer which was diagnosed in the final weeks of his life. The MacMillian nurses, along side the district nurses and carers,  provided outstanding care and support during this difficult time to both Steve and myself. They turned our home into a mini hospital overnight which enabled myself, Jack, Angela & Rick to provide care for him in the comfort of his own home. 

His funeral will take place on Monday 22nd March at 1:30pm at St. Peter’s and St. Paul’s Church Rishon and then 3pm at Pleasington Crematorium. 

Due to COVID19 restrictions,  the church and crematorium are invitation only and all invitees have now accepted. However, if you would like to gather outside any of the following places, ensuring social distancing rules, this is the route that Steve will be taking:

St. Peter's and St.Pauls Church - Rishton Cricket Club - Ewood Park - Crematorium   

If you would like to make a donation instead of sending flowers, please click the link.

Thank you for your condolences, cards and flowers that have been received over the last few days, it’s been truly overwhelming and is very much appreciated by us all.

We would like to say a very special thank you to our family and special friends who have supported us through this painful experience over the last few weeks; we couldn’t have got through it without you.

pageSummary: In memory of Colin Titmuss because he loved raising money for charity
pageSummaryWhy: he loved raising money for charity
story:
We suddenly lost dad at the age of 52, and his passing has left a void that will be impossible to fill. 

As many of you know, one of dads passions was arranging events to raise money for charity, including raising money for the Potters Bar train crash, and Brave the Shave for Macmillan Cancer Support. It is his caring, happy, and outgoing nature that we'd like dad to be remembered for. 

Thank you, the Titmuss Family xx

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
The past year and half has hit both our family circles hard through the impact of cancer. Natalia lost her Uncle John in September 2019 and then Donna lost her dad Joe in November the same year. 2020 didn't start any better with the loss of Natalia's grandad Bryan in February, leaving us both in shock at those devastating 6 months. More recently Donna's cousins daughter Poppy, who is only 9 years old, is bravely fighting a malignant tumour with surgery in the next few weeks. 

Although we have a fantastic support network around us, we have been left feeling useless so we have decided to raise some money to help those charities who have shown our family support and continue to do so. 

In our current lockdown state, exercise has been few and far between, so an easy 100 miles should be fine! :) We are going to attempt 100 miles before Easter Sunday with a mixture of walking and cycling. 

Thanks for reading and we hope you can give a little to these amazing causes. 

Natalia & Donna x

pageSummary: I am doing 100 squats a day in April because it's a charity that is very close to my heart.
pageSummaryWhat: I am doing 100 squats a day in April
pageSummaryWhy: it's a charity that is very close to my heart.
story:
This is in memory of my mum who was diagnosed with breast cancer and after a hard battle sadly died on the 14th February 2012. 

No one ever thinks that their family will be put through the type of pain cancer causes. Being thirteen at the time, I didn't understand why this had happened to my family. It's even harder to understand how it wasn't the cancer but a different illness that took my mum away from us. The last night I saw her she was feeling a lot better after being admitted to hospital with puenomia and I remember her being thankful her room had a TV so she could watch Eastenders. We said goodbye and see you tomorrow but tomorrow never came.

Despite the pain, the side effects of radiotherapy, giving up her job and having to use a wheelchair since being diagnosed, my mum continued to find strength and powered through until the end. 

In doing this I'm hoping to raise money for a brilliant charity and also channel my grief into something physical and help me work through my ongoing emotions about my mums passing (as my close friends know I find it difficult talking about my mum) 

So, this is for you mum. I hope you will have a great laugh watching me struggle through these pushups!

Thank you!


(If you want to follow my journey throughout April feel free to follow my instagram @laurenmaymott)

pageSummary: We are raising money because of the amazing work the nurses did helping Sadie.
pageSummaryWhy: of the amazing work the nurses did helping Sadie.
story:
Sadie was an extraordinary Wife, Mum, Grandma, Sister, Auntie and dear friend who touched so many people’s lives and will be remembered by many.

It is with deep sadness that we lost Sadie on the 27th February, following her extremely tough battle with Pancreatic Cancer. One of her last wishes was to provide as much support as possible to the wonderful charity of Macmillan nurses. The help and support given from the Macmillan nurses was absolutely brilliant, nothing was too much trouble.

Any donations to the page would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Dipak lost his father and brother-in-law due to Gall bladder cancer. Tauseef  lost his father due to Pancreatic cancer. 

Dipak's story

My father Dr Bijay Kumar Prasad, MBBS, DCH, MD died of pancreatic cancer in 1997. He was the only son of Late Hanuman Prasad of Nimej, Brahampur, Arrah District of Brahampur mela fame. My grand father was a landlord and had multiple properties in Calcutta but my father decided to study medicine and help the poor community in Bihar. He retired as a Civil surgeon of Patna. He was actively involved in setting  up and opening Mahavir Cancer Sansthan and Research Centre, Patna. During the last 10 years of his life he had dedicated himself to the Cancer Institute. While working at the Cancer institute project, he was diagnosed with the cancer and died within couple of months.

My brother-in-law Mr Prashant Bhagat, died of Gall bladder cancer at a tender age of 47. He was son of Late  Baijnath Prasad of Forbesganj, People in Purnia district used to know him as Lal Babu. Prashant had established himself as a very successful Businessman in Forbesganj and Araria and had developed an electronic business. He was very much involved in local charities to help the needy.

Dipak Raj, Consultant Orthopaedic Surgeon, Pilgrim Hospital, Boston, Lincolnshire, UK

Tauseef's story

My father Dr Syed Kamal Ashraf MS,FRCS,FICS died on February 7th , 2018 after a brief illness . He was the eldest son of the renowned landlord Aziz family of Chitkohra Patna. My father , as is known to all , was an eminent surgeon of Patna, He was trained in London. After training, he returned to India, initially joined PGI Chandigarh briefly and then moved to home town Patna and  worked at PMCH. He resigned when private practice was banned and had a successful career as an entrepreneur practising surgeon , having his own state of the art clinic called “Ashraf Clinic “ that he ran for a period that spanned almost five decades .In addition to his professional life , my father actively participated in social and philanthropic work.

Dr Tauseef Ashraf, Consultant Radiologist, Pilgrim Hospital, Boston, Lincolnshire, UK

 


About the challenge:  Tauseef and me will cover. a distance of 5847 miles ( 9409 km)  from Boston, UK  to Tokyo  in one year. We will cycle locally and update our cycling as and when we will do it. At the end this log will cover the distance. We will keep you updated with our efforts. We have accepted the challenge to collect at least £5847. 

About MacMillan:  At Macmillan, they give people with cancer everything they have got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are their worries. They are doing whatever it takes. But without your help they can’t support everyone who needs us.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

pageSummary: Throughout March I will be running 200km in total because we all know someone who's been affected by cancer
pageSummaryWhat: Throughout March I will be running 200km in total
pageSummaryWhy: we all know someone who's been affected by cancer
story: For those of you that know me, you’ll know that running is something that I really enjoy and do often, however this is a huge challenge that I’m setting myself with a target of averagely running 6.5km every single day to reach a grand total of 200km run during March. Even though this is a huge challenge for me, I’m extremely determined to reach this target in order to raise as much money as possible for Macmillan. Most of our lives have been touched by cancer in some way and the amazing work that Macmillan do is so vital in supporting and caring for those who are affected by the disease. I would be so grateful for any donation, no matter how big or small, and can’t say thank you enough for supporting me and supporting the fantastic work that this charity does.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
pageSummary: I am walking 2021 Miles across 2021 because they do such an awesome job
pageSummaryWhy: they do such an awesome job
story:
I set myself a walk challenge this year via #onemillionwomenwalking #walkchallenge. And one of my best friends Sheila, got diagnosed with cancer in 2018 and is using MacMillan who have been amazing so I thought I should just combine the two and make me HAVE to do this.

To put this total in context, I walked 1409 miles in 2020, starting because it was lockdown, and while I was working 8 hours a day, sat on my bum, at a desk, I had these 2 additional hours where I was not commuting. This worked well until I twisted my ankle and it never recovered properly. But I carried on anyway (as you do) until the end of October 2020 when I had major surgery and my ligament was rebuilt, cartilage was removed, and ankle was micro-fractured to replace it. That meant no putting my foot down for 6 weeks and no serious walking until after 12 weeks.

1409 miles from April to October… 2021 miles should be a “walk in the park”.

I worked out 2021 miles is about 5.5/12500 miles/steps a day – I was ok doing 5 miles already so ½ a mile was not going to be a challenge was it? Er… well…. If you factor in, I could not actually cover any distance in January, and if I go back to work I gain a 2-hour commute (lose my walking time), and I hate walking in the rain… it’s an actual challenge.

But its ok – I have a spreadsheet… and I am monitoring. Its currently March 7th – Since Jan 1st I have walked 705,821 steps against a target of 865,896 which is only 69 miles short… I will keep you updated… yes its a serious spreadsheet. 

And to be clear this is a “all in” steps challenge. I have a Fitbit counting my steps. If I am working, I do about 1000 steps across the course of the day (mostly answering the door to pick up another Amazon parcel) so it is mostly me making an effort to go out and actually walk.

So please donate, please donate all you can for those with cancer and need this service. They have helped so many people I know and love, and will continue to do so for a very long time.

Thank you very much

Gemma

PS My dog hates me, he is knackered…

PPS It is a year long challenge so I can bug you for donations until Jan 2022 just as we go back into lockdown...

pageSummaryWhat: I am baking a Huge cake with my Dad to raise cash!
pageSummaryWhy: my Gran experienced Cancer and I want 2 raise hope
story:
I am a 15 year old who wants to give back. My Grandma has gone through living with Cancer and her positive mindset has inspired me. I could see what she was going through, but she kept a smile on her face every day! If you have a family member like this then you will know how important they are and how lucky we are to have them around. I would be grateful to anyone that could donate to this special cause and I hope to post updates of how me and my Dad are getting on with our HUGE Cake. 

Maybe after Lockdown, you can all visit for a slice!

Lot's of love Soph

xxx

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Our dearly loved Mum, and wife, Jean, was diagnosed with terminal Kidney Cancer on the 23rd December 2020.  After a short and painful 10 weeks of nursing and caring for her at home with all her close family by her side, she sadly passed away peacefully on 3rd March 2021.  The specialist care teams, District Nurses and all medical professionals involved have been a god send through a very difficult and trying time to ensure mum was as comfortable as possible to the very end.

Please donate, however little, to ensure that others that are going through the same or similar situations get the best possible care wherever needed like Jean did.  Thank you x

pageSummary: I will be walking thousands of KM's in 2021
pageSummaryWhat: I will be walking thousands of KM's in 2021
story:
Over the years, I have listened to stories from people I love on the magnificent work Macmillan do to help and support those diagnosed and being treated for cancer.  

I don’t believe, until you have heard those words ‘you have cancer’ you really understand how valuable the connection to Macmillan is, or when treatment begins, how much of a lifeline they are in helping through the tough times.  

So, with these things there is always a story behind the choice of charity, and this is no different.  In December 2020, my dad was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer.  My dad, who unreservedly cares and supports my mum with MS and is the most loving and supportive dad in the world.

Starting treatment has been challenging, and the roller coaster of treatment cycles, blood tests, medication and weekly hospital visits coupled with sickness, tiredness, loss of appetite and get up and go has knocked the family for six.  

Whenever things get bad, or burning questions plague the mind, the Macmillan team are always there, ready to answer anything and to help and support whenever needed.  Not only for their patients either!  I’ve called a few times and have been treated with the same care and compassion as my dad.

 So, I plan to have a year of walking preparing for the following challenges to raise needed funds to help keep this vital lifeline to anyone who has been dealt the cancer card.  Please give whatever you can - and I’ll put the hours in to make you and more importantly, my dad proud.

pageSummary: We are challenging ourselves to cycle 20K because we want to say thank you!
pageSummaryWhat: We are challenging ourselves to cycle 20K
pageSummaryWhy: we want to say thank you!
story:
I (Riley) have decided to take up this 20K cycle challenge with my mum (Kaylee). We have been given the opportunity to take part in The castle virtual challenge - The March Hare. 

This will be a HUGE challenge as I’m still recovering from surgery! 

Last year I walked a marathon in lockdown to raise funds for a recumbent bike to allow me to have some fun and to help with my physio. Thanks to everyone’s huge generosity I managed to get my awesome bike and have been able to have some great adventures.

Now I want to use my amazing bike (and my muscles!) to give back. 20K is not going to be easy but knowing I’m raising money for such a great cause will keep me going. Macmillan helped us when my mum was going through cancer. So now we are going to cycle our butts off to give them a little something back. (Yep, mum is going to smash this too!)

Thank you so much for supporting our fundraising. 

YOU ARE AMAZING!

Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. story:
What is the 4x4x48 Challenge and why is it difficult?

The challenge is simple. Run 4 miles every 4 hours for 48 hours straight. That’s almost 2 marathons in 2 days.

Despite its simplicity, the 4x4x48 is a pressing test of resilience, endurance and willpower. Whilst 4 miles isn’t a major strain for most athletes, it’s the frequency of needing to run them which makes this challenge tough.

Because you have to put in 4 miles every 4 hours, you can’t get quality sleep. Sure, you might get the odd two and a half hours but the alarm bell will soon ring ordering you out of the comfortable bed and into the running shoes for another 4 miles.

Some find the wear and tear on the body particularly difficult. The first three or four 4-mile runs will be fine for most athletes but the constant running will soon result wear you out. Your muscles will start feeling sorer as the challenge progresses, and each run will become harder to maintain than the last.

The 4x4x48 challenge is also tough due to the willpower required. It’s easy to motivate yourself to run once or maybe even twice in a day but having to do so 12 times in 2 days is a sheer willpower test. Whilst you may be reading this thinking ‘easy, I’ll be able to take that on’, I guarantee you that (from personal experience) it’s a totally different conversation you’ll have with yourself when it’s 4AM on the second day and you’re exhausted.
title: Chris / Anthony / Scott / Leon 4x4x48

Name: Chris / Anthony / Scott / Leon 4x4x48

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
The Greene King IPA Rugby Championship ends on June 20th and to coincide with this date the Brewing & Brands’ & Pub Partners' divisions will take part in our Greene King Tr-IPA Championship commencing on Monday 22nd March for up to 90 days.

This challenge will see people across both divisions walk, run or cycle the distance between every Greene King IPA Championship ground over the course of the next 90 days. From Jersey to Cornish Pirates, to Nottingham to Saracens, we will be doing them all! The total mileage between all the grounds is 1715 miles which is a monumental amount, but colleagues will be coming together as teams and will all contribute to a team mileage total in an aim to reach the target.

Of course, we are doing this to raise money for our Official Charity Partner, Macmillan, who are doing everything to help people with cancer live life as fully as they can. But without vital funds it is impossible for them to do that, and any contribution you can make, both big or small, will be massively appreciated by all of us, not only in Brewing & Brands’ and Pub Partners' but throughout Greene King. 

This is quite a challenge, but we believe in our team of people that we can achieve this!

Thanks for reading, and thank you for your support.

story:
My name is Emily, I am taking part in a 'mighty hike' for Macmillan which includes hiking 26 miles on the 4th of Sept. 

I am hoping to raise money and awareness for people battling through any form of cancer. Both my grandads have lost their lives, my nanna, aunt and uncle battled through, my beautiful friend Nicole lost her life last year and most recently my dad has had his leg amputated and is currently amazingly building a new life around this. It's something close to my heart and I am wanting to try and give something back in rememberence/on behalf of them. 

The hike is in the lake district and I am completing this solo, I am hoping to raise well over the goal of £250, to ensure I pay my way and raise enough money to try and make a difference. 

'One person can make a difference, and everyone should try' - John F. Kennedy.

story:
Sadly cancer is constantly effecting a good portion of people. If it's ourselves, family or friends it can be devastating and hard to deal with. As a unit and a gaming community Taskforce G.R.I.D have come together to raise money for cancer research, We will be doing a full 24 hours gaming session as a team. Our main game focus is Arma so this will be our opening game in our schedule, We have a team of highly skilled mission builders and participants with thousands of hours game time combined.

Our main goal is to raise at least £250 pounds for Macmillan and more raised is just a bonus and more support for cancer patients. So join us on April the 9th at 1830 hours to help us fight cancer head on.

story:
I like to play video games on most nights to unwind and switch off from the real world. But this is usually for a few hours before rolling into bed.  So when I saw that Macmillan created a challenge for gamers to stream for 24hrs while playing and doing it to raise money, my eyes lit up...playing video games and campaigning to raise money for a good cause...what's not to like about that.

So this Good Friday 2nd April I am taking part in the Macmillan Game Heroes 24hr Challenge.

At Macmillan, they give people with cancer everything they’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are their worries. They’re doing whatever it takes. charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
We are raising money for Macmillan cancer support in memory of our friends Tristan and Daryll’s eldest son Dyllan. Tristan and Daryll have kindly written a few words about Dyllan’s story.

“Dyllan was just 18 months when diagnosed with Leukaemia in November 2015. Everything seemed well until he relapsed in April 2017 and unfortunately after many complications he sadly passed away October 2017.” 

“He will always be remembered as being very, very brave and will always be Forever 3 to everyone who knew him.” 

“Numerous charities helped over the years and Macmillan played a big part in putting us in touch with smaller charities who could also help. We wouldn’t have know about them if it wasn’t for Macmillan.”


The Coronavirus pandemic hasn’t changed how important charities such as Macmillan are but it has impacted the amount of donations that they have received over the past year because many fundraising events have not been able to take place. A gaming marathon is something that we are able to do in the current climate and we hope we will be able to make a small difference. Obviously being the fine athletes that  we are we would prefer to be running marathons or competing in an Iron Man triathlon but with the Coronavirus pandemic this just isn’t possible.

We will be making it a little bit harder this year by increasing the event from 24 hours to 26.2 hours to make it a true marathon. Starting at 06:00 on Friday 19th March and running through until 08:12 on Saturday 20th March. We will have a 10 minute break every 2 hours but the rest will be non-stop gaming. It might sound like fun but 24 hours has been a really difficult when we have done it before so 26.2 is really going to be a challenge.

The athletes taking part are:

Tommyrouse

le_spuff

LucasRAF

Si-mon119

Gibinstine69  

Thank you in advance for your kind donations!

pageSummary: I am gaming because cancer sucks.
story:
We're at it again!

For the fourth year, we will be raising money for Macmillan Cancer Support, a fantastic charity that helps support those living with cancer within the UK and their families .

Four years ago, our family lost a wonderful woman and Macmillan offered invaluable support in a very difficult time, so this is our way of giving back.

For more information on the work Macmillan do, please visit their website at https://www.macmillan.org.uk/ As always we will be undertaking a 12+ hour stream, this year on June 19th.

Please consider donating, and if you can't donate please share this page, and pop along to the stream on the day to show your support and get some hype going! Last year we raised an incredible £468.70, despite the pandemic being in full swing, bringing the total we have raised over the past 4 years to over £1,000! It would be absolutely fantastic if we could break £500 this year!

pageSummaryWhat: Raising money as part of my Duke of Edinburgh
pageSummaryWhy: they need donations to help people like you
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. As part of my Duke of Edinburgh Bronze Award I have chosen to raise money for St John Ambulance.

They are a charity that steps forward in the moments that matter. They save lives and keep communities safe. Their work is all funded by donations and this means the workers are volunteers and don't get paid. They also help out the NHS with Covid-19, and they are always at sports events and concerts. 

Please donate what you can to help. Thank you.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: St John Ambulance
pageSummary: For my bronze DofE, I'm going to tap for 24 hours because now, more than ever, their help is needed.
pageSummaryWhat: For my bronze DofE, I'm going to tap for 24 hours
pageSummaryWhy: now, more than ever, their help is needed.
story:
Hi, my name's Charlotte and I am 14 years old. I have chosen to raise money for St John Ambulance Service as part of the volunteering section of my Duke Of Edinburgh. 

I have been dancing since the age of five, and I decided to utilise these skills for my fundraising. As one of my favourite styles is tap, I am going to be attempting to tap dance for twenty-four hours straight. I will be doing this from the comfort of my own home, to make sure I stick to all the current Covid-19 restrictions.

St John Ambulance Service cover a range of different services, up and down the country. They can often be seen at a range of events, such as festivals, providing help and first aid for people should they need it. They also offer a wide range of first aid courses, teaching life saving skills such as CPR, as well as mental health courses. This training saves peoples lives. Their work is completely funded by donations, which is why fundraisers like the one I am completing are so important. 

Your donations, big or small, will all go directly to St John's. It would mean a lot if you would be able to donate, no matter the amount. Thank you!!

charity.name: St John Ambulance
story:
Miss Thomson, 5FTN class teacher has been a volunteer with St John Ambulance for two years and during the pandemic has adopted a new role. Since January, she has been helping the training team at the Stansted Airport Hypercenter to train up volunteers to work in vaccine centres across England. She has shared her role in the pandemic efforts with Year 5 and 6 students this week through a short assembly.

Following this, as a school we are keen to support Miss Thomson and St John Ambulance as a charity that rely on volunteers and donations. Funds are needed to maintain activities supporting the NHS in our COVID-19 response. The emergency is on-going, and St John Ambulance volunteers  continue to step forward to give vital support. 

Miss Thomson and a team in school will promote ‘Positive Post’ as a fundraising initiative - this would involve the children (and staff) taking some time to spread some positivity and kindness in the form of letters/drawings. These would be handed out on the last day of this term, March 26th following a quarantine period.

story:
On the 3rd April 2021 at 7.00pm, Luke and I are hosting an Easter Quiz Night, to raise funds for St John Ambulance!

The quiz is open for everyone to join in and is suitable for all age ranges, why not get the whole family involved!

To join, all that is asked is a small donation made through the JustGiving page. The suggested donation is £2 to join. Please make sure you use your full name when donating, thank you.

The quiz will be held on Microsoft Teams and if possible please have access to two devices connected to the internet, it is possible to use one device however the evening may be easier to follow using two.

There will be a prize for the 1st, 2nd and 3rd placed quizzers!

To access the quiz follow this link on the evening:
http://bit.ly/SJAEasterquiz

Happy quizzing!
Sarah Mansfield and Luke Stevenson
title: Spring into Action: Easter Quiz Night!!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Cody is raising money for St John's Ambulance by climbing 475 flights of stairs (the equivalent of mount snowdon) .. for someone that has hardly left his room in months this will be quite a mission 🤣

He is doing this as part of his Duke of Edinburgh award.  This last year has been tough to get the volunteer section done so he has opted to fundraise for this amazing charity 😁 

Please show some support and donate what you can :) 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: St John Ambulance
story:
This spring, spring clean your health and home to support St John Ambulance 

Springis the season of new beginnings for all. It is slowly getting warmer; the grass is getting a bit greener and the air feels a bit fresher. It is the perfect time of year to have a clean out and to get out! So this Spring why not Spring into Action for St John Ambulance and support our volunteers as they continue to step forward to give vital support to those in need across the country. 
 
Since the beginning of the COVID-19 outbreak our volunteers have given an incredible number of hours of support to patients in hospitals across the country, and we are not stopping. Throughout Spring we are continuing to mobilise thousands of volunteers to support the rollout of the COVID-19 vaccination. 
 
We need funds to maintain our activities supporting the NHS in our COVID-19 response. The emergency is on-going, and our volunteers will continue to step forward to give vital support. The work we deliver in our com

pageSummaryWhat: I am running my first ultramarathon
pageSummaryWhy: the training they provide is important to us all
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Having turned 30 this year I have decided it's now or never to achieve a life goal of completing an ultramarathon! The race will take place on the south coast and cover 100km (62 miles) in September of this year. Some more information on the ultramarathon can be seen here; https://ultrachallenge.com/south-coast-challenge/

I have taken this opportunity to raise money for the incredible staff at St John Ambulance. The work and training they provide touches all our lives at some point and over the past year they have become more important than ever. 

Any donation you can make will be greatly appreciated by myself, all those working for St John Ambulance.


Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummary: donating for CHD for my birthday than gifts because for our brave Lilly and everyone else with a CHD
pageSummaryWhat: donating for CHD for my birthday than gifts
pageSummaryWhy: for our brave Lilly and everyone else with a CHD
story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.


A little about our girl's story... At my 20 weeks scan we were giving news that ripped our hearts out no parent or mummy wants to hear. Our little Lilly had a health condition. As I got scans after scans about her heart Condition, it really is amazing what they can do before birth. We were very lucky as when Lilly was born they found out her heart condition wasn't as severe as they first thought. However, her heart is still very poorly but she was stable. We have recieved the best care she needed to be stable, until she got to the weight they wanted her to be, so they can fix her large hole (VSD) and anything else that needs fixed. To being told it is a VSD that needs fixed to being told at 23 weeks she needed a whole repair, you can imagine how the positives are what we hold onto each day. 

Lilly struggles a lot but she is still stable and everyday she proves doctors wrong and shows how much she just carries on achieving new milestones everyday.  We are so proud of her and how brave she is at only 5 months. It is amazing how resilient babies and kids are and we see this everyday with our girl. It has been tough, a few scary moments but she has bounced back and really thriving.  Lilly has a heart veering to the right  (dextrocardia) A large hole  (VSD) and I think Transportation of the great arteries (TGA) It is very complex as their main concern is the large VSD. Bless her, so scans are every complex but all doctors have managed so well. Anyway I could go and on about our Lilly as she is our miracle fighter from day one! 

So please, if you are able to help give a little to families with loved ones that have CHD, we would really appreciate this. Thank you for all the support we have been giving to help Lilly with her condition. Teddies, love, advice and a virtual hug when needed. We know these times are hard but just seeing and hearing the love has gotten us all through.

story:
John sadly past away suddenly on the 25th of February 2021. John had time for everyone and was very well respected. This news has come as a shock to many people. John's funeral has been planned on Monday the 22nd at 2pm. Due to coronavirus restrictions the family have taken to the the difficult decision to invite family members only. 

Comments, tributes and donations to the British Heart Foundation in John's memory can be made through this page alternatively you can send a cheque to G.T Edwards 126, Nottingham Road, Ilkeston, DE7 5NW. I have been asked that you clearly explain that this is a donation for the British heart foundation in John Welsh's memory. 

G.T Edwards can only take cheques up to 2 weeks after John's funeral and so this page will also be closed around a similar time. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

eventName: 60 miles walking in March for the British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I'm taking part in the POSH100K Challenge because I love to walk and want to help a great cause.
pageSummaryWhat: I'm taking part in the POSH100K Challenge
pageSummaryWhy: I love to walk and want to help a great cause.
story: The British Heart Foundation turns 60 this year and we wanted to mark the occasion so with support from Peterborough United Football Club the challenge is to walk/run/cycle the equivalent of 60 miles (100K) during the month of March (31 days). This equates to roughly 2miles/3K per day. This is aimed at getting everyone in Peterborough moving following lockdown, improving their health and wellbeing. If we could get 100 people signed up to each raise just £60, Peterborough could raise an amazing £6,000 to fund our life saving research and help those 86,000 people in Cambridgeshire living with Heart and Circulatory diseases. Please use the hashtag #POSH100K in any social media posts to hopefully create some noise in the City about our challenge.

pageSummary: In Loving Memory of Rajan Anandan because BHF is an Important & Worthwhile Cause
pageSummaryWhat: In Loving Memory of Rajan Anandan
pageSummaryWhy: BHF is an Important & Worthwhile Cause
story:
We're collecting vital funds for the British Heart Foundation, to power pioneering research into heart and cardiovascular diseases. The money we raise will help beat heartbreak forever.

On the 11th of February 2021 our Dad suddenly and sadly passed away. Rajan Anandan was a devoted husband to Sheena and an Amazing father . He leaves five Grandchildren who he loved and endlessly spoilt. The family would prefer donations to be made to the BHF rather than receive flowers and wreaths , so that we leave a legacy to others who will benefit from this Donation Gift.

The funeral is on the 17th of March & because of COVID19 restrictions the funeral numbers are strictly monitored. If you wish to attend please contact the family . with kind Regards Emiley & Sean.

pageSummaryWhat: A month without Chocolate- harder than it sounds!!
pageSummaryWhy: The work done by bhf is close to my heart x
story:
Most of you know that I'm registered disabled, this means that I  can't run marathons, climb mountains or cycle the length of the UK.  But I do want to support the British Heart Foundation as much as I can. I'm joining their month long challenge to raise funds by giving up chocolate- it may not sound much but at the moment I think the mountain climb may be easier. 

Please could you kindly give a little to help my fundraising, I would appreciate all the support that I can get. Thanks.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I'm doing the Yorkshire Three Peaks Challenge because this money helps fund life-saving research.
pageSummaryWhat: I'm doing the Yorkshire Three Peaks Challenge
pageSummaryWhy: this money helps fund life-saving research.
story:
This summer I'll be hiking up and down Yorkshire's three highest peaks to raise money for the British Heart Foundation!
Working on a team of vascular scientists funded by the BHF, we have used some of the money raised by people like you to understand cardiovascular disease and help beat heartbreak! lped improve and save the lives of many people with heart and circulatory diseases.
£5 pays for 125 microscope slides, essential for researchers to study how faulty heart cells look like. £10 pays for a researcher toolkit, containing all the test-tubes, flasks, dishes and gloves a team of hypertension researchers will use in a day. £25 pays for one hour of research facilities and materials used by us to simulate heart disease in the laboratory and investigate how new drugs can help.

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but we have a long way to go! It's only thanks to support from people like you that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures.

story: As many of you might know I lost my mum (Jane) last year on the 14th of April from heart disease and it was the hardest time of my families lives. Thank you

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
eventName: London to Brighton Off-Road Bike Ride 2021
story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.

pageSummary: I am taking on the Yorkshire 3 Peaks because I want to raise money in memory of my late Grandad
pageSummaryWhat: I am taking on the Yorkshire 3 Peaks
pageSummaryWhy: I want to raise money in memory of my late Grandad
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation in memory of my Grandad Ron and I'd be grateful for your support. 

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. With more research I hope that in my Grandad's memory I can support the British Heart Foundation in helping someone else's family. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. I really appreciate your donation, however small. 

I'll be taking on the three highest peaks in Yorkshire: Pen-y-ghent (694m), Whernside (736m) and Ingleborough (723m) covering 24 miles and 5,000 feet of climbing, facing rocky terrain and steep climbs. All three peaks must be completed in 12 hours, but I am aiming for a target of 8 hours.

I appreciate your donation, however small, especially in the challenging times many of us are currently facing. 

Thanks for your support.

George

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
eventName: 10km in memory of Mark Holmes & Brad Morgan - Supporting the British Heart Foundation
story:
We have organised a 10km run on Sunday 25th April in memory of Mark Holmes and Brad Morgan, Dad's to our close friends Ben, Luke and Jack. 

We sadly lost Brad and Mark over Christmas time to Covid-19 which came as a huge shock to us all. Brad and Mark played an absolutely huge part of their family and friends lives and positively impacted the lives of so many around them. 

Anyone is welcome to run, walk or even just come for a few drinks after to celebrate the memory of Brad and Mark and this great charitable cause.

All proceeds will go to the British Heart foundation as this was a charity that Mark supported. The BHF has become one of the largest and best known charities in the UK. They have built a track record of funding ground-breaking heart research that has transformed cardiac treatment and care. Their work has helped to cut UK deaths from cardiovascular disease by more than half.

Event details are as follows:

We will start and finish the run at the Brave Nelson pub (138 Woodman Rd, Warley, Brentwood CM14 5AL). Start time is 11:30am and the running route will be printed and given out to anyone who needs it. Parking is facilitated at the pub. 

Please contact me if you would like anymore information or the details of the event - 07951 543 398.

story:
Father Lawrence Smith died unexpectedly in January this year. As a family we have decided that whilst we will have a small floral tribute at Dads funeral we would rather those wanting to show their appreciation for Dad and all he did through his life donate the cost of flowers to one of two charities:

The British Heart Foundation or Diabetes UK

Thank you for showing your love in this way and we thank you all. It is an added sadness that in the current climate we cannot hold a celebration for all Dads friends and colleagues to attend but we thank you for your time and ask you say a prayer for Dad. Thank you x

Please select your chosen charity of preference.

If everyone gives a little together we can raise a lot. Thank you x

story:

We miss her.

Her loving (but hungry) children

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Jai Ambe 

We have set up this page in memory of our much loved Ajabapa who sadly passed away on Sunday 7th March 2021 at the age of 81. 

Our Ajabapa was a kind and humble family man who was a pillar of the community. A person with so much happiness and lived life to the fullest, always learning and exploring throughout his life. An inspiration to us all.

We have set up this page for anyone who would like to donate to The British Heart Foundation. Our Ajabapa was a very generous man and we know that he would want us to give back, to help those in need if we can. We will be extremely grateful for any donations that may help people through this charity. 

Your generosity & support are appreciated at this difficult time.

On behalf of Khushabhai's Family.

Thank you.

Jai Shree Krishna 🙏

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Dad was born with a hole in the heart in 1947 and was only given a year to live.  He was operated on in March 1958 by Professor A L d'Abreu and Leon Abrahams, using the heart/lung machine designed and invented by Professor Melrose.  Dad was only the 25th child in the United Kingdom to undergo this operation.  After a long recovery, Dad went on to live a full and healthy life.

We as a family would like to donate to the British Heart Foundation in memory of our dearly loved and missed husband, father, grandfather and uncle, in support of all the amazing research and work they continue to do.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Our dear Mum Janet Pearson grew her angel wings on 23rd February after a short illness, leaving us all devastated. 

Both Mum & Dad have had heart problems and are grateful for all the research and development from the BHF. Mum was adamant that she didn't want flowers at her send off but for people to donate to the BHF in her memory if they wished to. 

From us all I send thanks to you all for your kind messages, cards and flowers we have had sent to us. Mum loved life...we must continue to love it in her memory. She has left a legacy that will never be forgotten.

Sleep tight Mum...until we hold each other again in Heaven.

With eternal love from Rob, Mel, Jan, Peanut and all your grandchildren and great grandchildren xx

story:
Sadly, Dad passed away on the 18th Feb after a short, but brave, fight against Covid-19.

Unfortunately, he had a number of health issues  which lessened his chances against this nasty virus.

Foremost of these was Heart Failure, which he had been living with for the last few years.

With mum also suffering her own major cardiac event a couple of years ago, the family has been supporting the BHF ever since and would therefore be very grateful if anyone is able to make a donation to this very worthy charity, in Dad’s memory.

Many thanks

Ann, Simon & Debbie

story:

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit.

Charles (Chas) Griffiths sadly passed away on 22nd February this year just a day before his 79th birthday. His funeral will be held at the Kent and Sussex crematorium on the 23rd March.

Chas spent a great deal of his time working with the Lions Club to support many different charitable causes both local and national so it is fitting that we ask that those wishing to remember him make a small donation to the British Heart Foundation instead of sending flowers.

Chas will be greatly missed by everyone, family and friends alike.

pageSummary: Asking for donations instead of floral tributes
pageSummaryWhat: Asking for donations instead of floral tributes
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Lauryn's Story.

Back in the year  2000, our Angel was born.. a week early on the 18th. November. She was our bundle of joy, our light our life. Sadly we were hit, just 6 weeks later, with the news that Lauryn had a heart defect. It was later diagnosed as being dilated cardiomyopathy. We were told that because of the severity of her heart, she may need a transplant by the time she was two. We were broken..but carried on for our gorgeous bubbly girl. The next couple of years were spent in numerous hospitals...including Great Ormond Street and Glenfield Hospitals. It was a long, hard journey but we got through it, mainly due to Lauryn's resilience, strength and will to succeed. But we would have been lost without the amazing support we got from all hospitals and the staff involved in Lauryn's care. I would like make a special mention to Dr. Bu'lock at Glenfield Hospital, nothing was ever too much trouble for this amazing lady. We were eventually sent home with a truck load of medicines, pumps and other medical kit,  and of course our princess, to get on with our lives...it was scary at first but we got through it. With the odd admissions and medication tweak  in between, Lauryn lived a near to complete life for the next 16 years. In February 2019, 3 months after her 18th birthday,  Lauryn suddenly took ill. After a few hospital checks, we were told she needed a heart transplant. We were both shocked and devastated, when we were told. Lauryn was finally admitted to Papworth Hospital and had her heart transplant on the 26th. April 2019. Once again, the staff at both City and Papworth hospitals were amazing, ensuring that Lauryn got the best care. Lauryn was also amazing, she was strong, brave and determined, a true fighter throughout this journey, we were so proud of our beautiful girl...so proud. Her transplant was successful and La was discharged on 17th May 2019. I am hurting so badly as I write this, as apart from 1 minor blip, Lauryn remained healthy.  After her transplant we hoped and prayed that Lauryn would lead a full and happy life and she was..she was enjoying life again! Sadly Lauryn passed away suddenly on 7th. February 2020.  Our  heart's have been ripped out..there is now a huge void in our lives.. Lauryn fought admirably through every stage of her wonderful life...only for it to be taken away so abruptly. Our angel Lauryn - we will always love you.. you will always be with us - you will always inspire us. Fly high princess xxxx

Please help save lives by supporting this charity - a small donation could make a big difference. Thank you xx

story:
This page has been set up in memory of our dear dad who passed away suddenly on 22nd February 2021. 

Dad had a number of charities that were dear to him and that he supported himself. 

Dad relied on the British Heart Foundation before and after his bypass surgery in 2017.  The provided invaluable support to him as he learnt to live with his heart condition. He followed their suggestions to the letter! 

Any donations made in dad's memory will go towards the foundations continuing work in research and support for other patients and their families.

Thank you for your support.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

After heartbreakingly losing my Brother to a sudden Heart attack recently and the hospital trying to save him the best way they know how, I feel it’s important to try raise some awareness and help fundraise for this charity in the hope more can be done to help people look after their heart and help the hospital professionals have every possible chance they have to save more lives. 

Our Dad also previously suffered a heart attack and  eventually was given a double heart bypass. The care and attention of the experts was second to non and Some of the money raised by the British Heart Foundation was used to kit out the visitors room on the heart wards  for things like books, hot drinks, tissues, counselling or support for families which for us made the treacherous time a little slightly more comfortable and easier to deal with . 


On behalf of me and my Business Danum Home hardware we will be doing a huge charity drive to raise as much as we can to help please help me by sharing my go fund me page or donating to this cause 🙏

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
As you may have heard, we lost my beloved Grandad Donald Veitch on the 14/2/2021. He was an amazing husband, father, grandparent and all round special, warm and kind hearted person who will be greatly missed.

His Family have all decided to do something special in his name by fundraising money towards an agreed Charity, The British Heart Foundation and invite anyone who is interested in donating, however much or little they can, to do so through this page in remembrance of Don. 

Thank you all for your caring thoughts and generous donations, during this tough time for our family.
title: Remembering Don [1938-2021]

Name: Remembering Don [1938-2021]

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. charity.name: British Heart Foundation
eventName: In memory of Dawn  Hatton Nee Collett
story:
To everyone that knew our mum Dawn Hatton nee Collett.

 As most of you will be aware Dawn recently passed away due to COVID-19 and pneumonia. This was a shocking and very sudden, heartbreaking way for her to leave us and we have a huge hole in our hearts that will sadly never be filled. We are choosing to have donations given to the British Heart Foundation as this seems a charity most relevant and personal to our mom with her suffering with heart troubles herself. Dawn had Atrial Fribrillation, meaning one of the valves to her heart could not pump the blood around to her heart properly. This caused her shortness of breath, irregular heart rhythm and palpitations, and after having numerous scans and procedures, She was fitted with a defibrillator. As time went on she still suffered the strain of her health until her unfortunate passing on Monday 1st February 2021. 

Any donations will be greatly appreciated and happily received in honour of our beautiful mom Dawn xx

Thankyou from her children

Richard & Ashleigh xxx

story: I am running daily in memory of my Bruce Duncan Falconer who sadly passed on 28 November 2020 aged just 57 of a heart related condition. I aim to do around 180 miles between 1 March 2021 and 3 June 2021. Bruce would have been 58 on the 3 June 2021 and the British Heart Foundation is a great charity and a fitting cause. Bruce worked at Peppers Trinity Square for most of his career. Support from anyone, particularly those who knew Bruce personally, would be most appreciated

Thank you.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
We are sad to say that on Saturday 13th February Mum/Susan lost her biggest battle and we are all absolutely devastated.

She was a wonderful wife, mum, sister, nan and friend.  Everyone that knew her will feel the loss of her passing in so many ways.

She embraced life, loved holidays and was always, always there for her family and friends.  Our hearts are heavy, but we know that she would have wanted some good to come out of such a sad situation.

We will be holding a funeral service on Wednesday 24th March at 2.30pm.  Due to the current restrictions we cannot accommodate all of the people that we know would have loved to remember Mum/Sue, but there will be an internet link for anyone that would like to join us from home.

Please email lisa.leahy@faraday.com or call Lisa 07950 503771 for the link.

Whilst Mum/Sue loved flowers and always had them in the house she said several times over the years that she would like donations made to charity in her name instead of floral arrangements.

If you would like to send a floral tribute, they would be welcomed at:- W.S. Cole & Son, 17-19 High street, Minster, Ramsgate CT12 4BU on 24th March before 12 noon.  

However, if you would like to donate to the British Heart Foundation in lieu of flowers then we would be honoured as this is a cause very close to Mum/Sue's heart and we are sure it would make her smile.

Thank you for any donations made.

Ian, Lisa, Clair and Robert
title: In loving memory of Susan Bye
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Susan Bye
Name: In loving memory of Susan Bye

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Although Auntie Margaret was 93 and had some serious health problems I somehow believed that she would manage to go on forever and outlast us all.  It still doesn't feel real that she has gone and I have found myself picking up the phone some evenings ready for our evening chat.  

Auntie was a special person and I always admired her strength and determination.  Even in later years there were few obstacles which prevented her from getting what she wanted done.   The one thing Aunty valued more than anything else was her independence.  So although its sad that she has left us so unexpectedly I am so grateful that she held on to her independence to the very end.     

As some of you may know Auntie suffered with several different heart conditions for much of her adult life.  Until the last few years she never allowed the problems to restrict her activities and no doubt her cardiologist would have been horrified if he had known some of the things she used to get up to.  Apparently more than half of us will suffer with a heart or circulatory condition during our lives.

I am sorry that due to the current restrictions some of you will not be able to attend the funeral ceremony in person.  However hopefully you will be able to view the ceremony from the comfort and safety of your own homes using the webcast facilities.  I have included the details for joining the broadcast below for convenience.  

Ceremony -              23-Mar-21 at 2:00
Chapel -                    North - Chelmsford
Website -                  https://www.obitus.com/
Username -              Sabe5116
Passcode -              562256

pageSummaryWhy: John died of heart failure as did his siblings
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page

My wonderful, kind hearted loving dad John Vickers passed away last week of heart failure / dementia 😭 

If any of our family and friends would like to donate money to the  British Heart Foundation instead of sending flowers to the funeral we would appreciate that, as heart failure has been the cause of death for all his family.  In 1999 dad had a heart valve replacement giving him an extra 22 years, we are so grateful for those 22 years and wants to help others through the research of the British Heart Foundation 

All monies raised will be used to help others

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

Help Lily, Nat and Charlie keep off the sweet stuff this month with a donation of your choice. xx

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
eventName: 5K a day through March 2021 - for every 5 GBP raised I will walk / run 5K
pageSummaryWhy: its for a great cause and good being involved
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

pageSummary: I am raising much needed money because they are a fantastic cause that mean a lot to me.
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising much needed money
pageSummaryWhy: they are a fantastic cause that mean a lot to me.
story: So once again I've decided to give up one of my favourite things for a whole month - chocolate! It is in aid of a great cause, the British Heart Foundation, who carry out vital research into one of the biggest killers in the UK. As a cardiology nurse it is something I am very passionate about. Please donate what you can to this fantastic cause! Thank you so much 🙂

pageSummary: I am completing the March 2021 Dechox because they are an extremely worthy charity!
pageSummaryWhat: I am completing the March 2021 Dechox
pageSummaryWhy: they are an extremely worthy charity!
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge the BHF has faced in its 60 year history and led to them being forced to make the devastating decision to cut their 2020 research budget in half.  

I’m fundraising for a lovely friend who I used to work with named Laura Barlow. Laura sadly lost her life very young and I would like to raise funds for this vital charity in her memory. Laura was extremely kind and loving. I know everyone that knew her misses her very much.  Please donate to help people suffering heart problems, such as the one Laura had.

I am giving up all chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks for March to raise funds for the BHF to continue their amazing work!! Thank you.

pageSummary: Dechox March! because It is important to help the BHF.
pageSummaryWhy: It is important to help the BHF.
story:
As a British Heart Foundation volunteer, I am feeling inadequate, as it is not easy to fund raise at the moment.  So when the B.H.F. decided to make March a Dechox month (give up chocolate for the month) I signed up to try and raise some money!

My pledge is to not eat chocolate (or chocolate cake) for the month of march, for those that know me will know this is a real challenge.  Thank you for taking the time to read this and any sponsorship is gratefully received. x

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
