Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. story: Thanks for visiting the page. As team, we are raising money for the British Heart Foundation and we'd be so grateful for your support! The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help us hit our target. Thanks!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I am doing a dechox in March because I think that this is a brilliant cause.
pageSummaryWhat: I am doing a dechox in March
pageSummaryWhy: I think that this is a brilliant cause.
story:
I have various personal reasons for doing this challenge, which I won't go into here.

I will however say that the work that the British Heart Foundation does is brilliant and they would have far less funds in 2020-2021 because of the pandemic.

They have been forced to make the devastating decision to cut their 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. 

It has been a test of willpower though great to know that we can all take steps to contribute towards ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. 

Despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I am raising money by making felt hearts because as we know everyone has a heart
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising money by making felt hearts
pageSummaryWhy: as we know everyone has a heart
story:
Thank you for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation by selling my scented felt hearts. Ever since having bypass surgery in 2009 I have been making batches of these hearts and selling them for people to use as Christmas decorations, hang on door handles, clothes hangers or pop inside birthday cards. They are quite fiddly to make but I enjoy doing them nonetheless. I can remember so clearly the day I had my heart attack and am very thankful for the experts who did what they needed to do and here I am 12 years later. 

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit and exceed my target. Thank You.
title: Maureens Heart Felt Challenge

I am giving up any form of chocolate for the whole of march to raise some money for the British heart foundation.. 

This charity is very close to me after losing my grandad (2012) and nan (2019) both to heart attacks  ❤


The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Val/Peter Middleton/England
Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I am starving myself to help others!
pageSummaryWhat: I am starving myself to help others!
story:
Welcome to my Just Giving Page! If you would like to donate some money to the British Health Foundation to reflect the enormous sacrifice I am making (giving up chocolate), please do.

I am also trying to make a dent in my ever expanding lockdown belly. 

For both of these worthy causes I will not be eating any chocolate treats for the entire month of March. That's 31 days without eating any delicious chocolate... 

I know it sounds like madness but that's what I've agreed to do: No chocolate. None at all. Not even the little flaky bits on top of coffee or a sneaky Easter egg before bed. 

So to be clear I'm saying NO to:

Peppermint Creams, Mars, Snickers, Topics, Dairy Milk Chocolate, Caramels, Double Deckers, Smarties, Picnics, Crunchies, Turkish Delights, Tubs/boxes of Heros, Tubs/boxes of Quality Street, Boxes of Maltesers, Share bags of Giant Chocolate Buttons, Share bags of Revels, Chocolate cakes, Chocolate muffins, Chocolate chip pancakes and cookies and ...

...smooth creamy luxurious hot chocolate drinks.... with marshmallows on top... drizzled in sticky sweet syrup...

..

..

Nobody really expects me to do this do they?

pageSummary: I am giving up chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks! because I want to help raise money for equipment
pageSummaryWhat: I am giving up chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks!
pageSummaryWhy: I want to help raise money for equipment
story: Someone very close to me has tetralogy of fallot (TOF) where the pulmonary vessel is thinner than it should be and there is a gap between the two heart chambers which separates the red and blue blood. I want to help raise money for the equipment needed to do the relevant research. Please help me raise money towards this cause as I will also be donating the money that I would have spent on my chocolate! Even if it’s just a £1 anything would be much appreciated xxxx

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I am part of the fun campaign March 2021 because of the brilliant treatment received in Derriford
pageSummaryWhat: I am part of the fun campaign March 2021
pageSummaryWhy: of the brilliant treatment received in Derriford
story:
Spurred on by my wonderful treatment in Derriford Hospital January 2021. All this in the middle of the highest peak of CoViD 19 care the Hospital was delivering. Dedication and care was so focused you’d think it was a quiet Sunday in middle of summer with all the time in the world and me being the only emergency patient that day!

Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for visiting my page 

I'm doing the 4/4/48 running challenge to raise money for The British heart foundation a fantastic charity who I’ve recently done a few challenges for any donation will be greatly received 


The challenge is simple. Run 4 miles, every 4 hours, for 48 hours. I will be recording each run on Strava and also be posting about each leg on my Twitter @dpnattrass

 

I will be starting on Thursday the 1st of April 2021 in the evening at 6pm and finishing at the same time on Saturday the 3rd of April 


The reason I’m doing this is well why not I’m curious to see how far I can actually push myself and thought why not raise some money for a great charity at the same time. I’ve recently been setting myself challenges and this is the next one that really interested me after my marathon run back in February 


So from 6 on Thursday April the 1st I will be running 4 miles every 4 hours for 48 hours and covering 48 miles in the process over the two days  


Thanks in advance for any donations in advance as it will push me on massively on my 2am runs 😂
title: Dec's 4-4-48 challenge
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Dec's 4-4-48 challenge

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
As a result of the latest developments, we are unable to go ahead with thousands of collections planned across the UK in the coming months. Guide Dogs remains committed to supporting people with sight loss across the UK.

It has never been more important to come together online and support one another. We appreciate times are difficult right now, but for people with sight loss, social isolation can be their every day. 

By hosting a virtual collection for Guide Dogs, every pound you or your group raises will ensure we can continue to help people with sight loss and feel less alone, now and in the future. It costs £13 a day to support each of our life changing dogs.

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
Almost two million people in the UK are living with sight loss that has a significant impact on their daily lives. Of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone and lead lonely, isolated lives. 

Guide Dogs works for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life, for a world where being blind or partially sighted is not what defines you. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling hopes and dreams.

Thanks You!

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. pageSummary: We're two little people raising money because they are amazing and help so many people.
pageSummaryWhat: We're two little people raising money
pageSummaryWhy: they are amazing and help so many people.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We are Small and Tiny, two little people who have been working on a project to help promote an amazing charity. Please help us, by sharing our video far and wide. The more that see it, the more opportunity we have of reaching our fundraising target. The target of £250 will provide 10 amazing hours of puppy training. Can you help? 

"Hello my name is Cupcake and I’m going to be a guide dog when I grow up. It’s a bit like a superhero dog. I’m so excited. 😆 

My daddy was a guide dog too. He lived with a lady called Wendy who was blind. My daddy helped her cross the road, go to work and get to the shops. Daddy was like Wendy’s eyes and she got to do amazing things because of him. 

I’ve had a health check and I’m going to live with someone called a Puppy Walker. Then I’ve got to go to training school and get my own harness and learn about the world. All very important superhero jobs. 

It costs lots of money to do all our training, but kind hero humans give money to the Guide Dogs for the Blind Association. 

Maybe you can help too? Have a look at guidedogs.org.uk on your computer thingy. 

Woof... Bye."

To help share our little video about the great work Guide Dogs do for their owners, please share this video with your friends. Thank you.
Video link: https://youtu.be/r0A-BivqnuA

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
The sponsored walk thats good for the sole.

Your small steps will help Guide Dogs make giant leaps. Just one week of stepping can make a difference to the life of children and adults living with sight loss. Raise over £50 (£25 for children) and well replace those worn out socks with a brand-new Guide Dogs pair designed by an international fashion icon!

How your funds will change lives...

-	£50 could pay for fun, tactile activities to help children co-ordinate their muscles and movements.

-	£96 could pay for an eye test each for two guide dogs in training

-	£116 could buy a Training School Kit for one of our guide dog trainers who will teach pups the specialist skills they need as fully qualified guide dogs.

-	£710 could buy a Birthing Kit containing all the essential equipment for a guide dog mum to safely deliver her puppies.

Its thanks to people like you that we can continue to provide life-changing services. So, a huge thank you and lots of luck for your challenge!

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

pageSummary: I am running these events because they make a real difference to people's .lives
pageSummaryWhy: they make a real difference to people's .lives
story:
this page has been set up to support Guide Dogs with my runs in the London Landmarks Half Marathon and any other events (real or virtual) that I take part in during 2021

As you may know the LLHM has been postponed until later in the year owing to the ongoing Coronavirus crisis. I hope to run the real LLHM if it takes place this year

Anyway that's the situation, I hope to run the virtual Edinburgh and Loch Ness Marathons and the Great North Run later in the year if they 'happen'.

As Guide Dogs (and all other charities) are suffering in the current crisis any donations would be gratefully appreciated.

Thank You

Iain
﻿NB: You can still see how I got on last year at www.justgiving.com/iainlewis15

WHO ARE GUIDE DOGS?

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation. Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss. We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

pageSummary: I am running The GNR half marathon to raise money because I love dogs and want to help make a difference!
pageSummaryWhat: I am running The GNR half marathon to raise money
pageSummaryWhy: I love dogs and want to help make a difference!
story:
A very close friend of mine Jen, started running last year and took on the Couch to 5k. I started running to help support her and keep her motivated. Mission accomplished she then signed up to a 10-21k!  I wasn't impressed 😂 When I saw she'd signed up to do The Great North Run this year, I felt it only fair to be by her side and see it through to the end - all 21k of her personal challenge. I must be mad! 🏃🏼‍♀️

So I am running 13.1 miles this September. I'm doing it for Jen, I'm doing it for me, I'm doing it for my Mum (she always wanted to do the GNR but got a knee injury) and I'm doing it to raise money for Guide Dogs! 🦮😍

I work with dogs 🐩 every day and love how much they mean to us. They bring so much positivity into our lives, physically, emotionally and mentally and it amazes me how so many dogs are trained to help, support and save us in a multitude of ways.

2 years ago I was referred to an optometrist about my eyes and have been back again recently. Thankfully my eyes are healthy but due to family glaucoma I have been told to get annual tests to keep an eye on it - no pun intended 😉 It has made me value my eyesight and appreciate life with sight.  I want to pay it forward and Guide Dogs seemed a perfect charity choice for me. 🦮

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation. Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss. We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:
Thank you for pledging your sporting challenge for 2021. Whether you are running, cycling, skydiving or taking part in an extreme challenge, you are making it count for Guide Dogs. We hope you are raring to go and proud of yourself for joining our team of life-changers! 

The sponsorship money you raise will truly make a difference. £140 could buy a Starter Kit for a new guide dog owner, containing everything they need to start a life with their new guide dog, this includes the iconic white harness. 

Its thanks to people like you that we can continue to provide life-changing services, like our guide dogs, to people with sight loss. So, a huge thank you and lots of luck for your challenge!

charity.description: We fundraise to enhance Great Ormond Street Hospital’s ability to transform the health and wellbeing of children and young people. Donations help to fund advanced medical equipment, child and family support services, pioneering research and rebuilding and refurbishment.
charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story: In 2021 the London Small Business Banking team of HSBC UK are raising money for Great Ormond Street Hospital through various events. Great Ormond Street Hospital is an international center of excellence in child healthcare. Since its formation in 1852, the hospital has been dedicated to children's healthcare and to finding new and better ways to treat childhood illnesses. Your support helps Great Ormond Street Hospital fund pioneering discoveries that help saving young lives every day. Every donation helps to beat childhood illnesses. Thank you.

pageSummary: Caitlin’s sponsored walk because Caitlin decided to get fit and raise cash for kids
pageSummaryWhy: Caitlin decided to get fit and raise cash for kids
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Caitlin is really excited to walk 2 miles a day for the whole of March to raise money for the children and staff at Great Ormond Street Hospital. Charities have been hit hard by Covid and their annual fundraisers have been lost due to social distancing and lack of events like the Great North Run and Tough Mudder. So we’re just trying to do our bit to keep things ticking away at the hospital as they’re heavily reliant on fundraising to maintain their level of high tech interventions for sick kids. 

Thanks for reading and if you can spare a little we would be greatly appreciative.

Vicky and Caitlin xx

pageSummary: In memory of albies grandad Colin because Our son has had kidney bladder and heart surgery.
pageSummaryWhat: In memory of albies grandad Colin
pageSummaryWhy: Our son has had kidney bladder and heart surgery.
story:
So as most of you know our son Albie is a patient at great ormond street and has had a few operations there already and will be going back in soon for his open heart surgery so we will be walking 62 miles in March in memory of his grandad Colin Trigg who sadly passed away Christmas morning. We are hoping to raise a little money for Albie and all the children like him that have depended on great ormond street and we will be forever grateful to them for fixing our little boy 💙
We would be really grateful for just £1 or £2 💙
Albie nanny June decided to have money donations for great ormond street in place of flowers and that has raised £300 so I’d to raise £200 and make it up to £500 if possible xx

Any money raised from now on will be in colins memory and will be on this page. 

Thanks for visiting our fundraising page.We've joined together to raise money for charity, and your donation can make all the difference.Remember: Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never share them with anyone or send you unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. They'll make sure Gift Aid (an additional 25%) is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer, too. That means more money goes to the charity, faster, with JustGiving.

pageSummary: I am raising money with my Virtual Charity Quiz because Of the amazing work it does in our communities
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising money with my Virtual Charity Quiz
pageSummaryWhy: Of the amazing work it does in our communities
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

This week’s Virtual Charity Pub Quiz is raising money for Great Ormond Street Hospital.This extraordinary hospital has helped so many families, including personal friends of mine.
Every day brings new challenges at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH). Every day, 619 children and young people from across the UK arrive for life-changing treatments.
Every day, young lives hang in the balance as patients, families and staff battle the most complex illnesses. Every day, the brightest minds come together to achieve pioneering medical breakthroughs that change the lives of thousands of children – and change the world.
Despite the greatest challenges a child can face, the hospital is a place where being sick does not always mean being sad. And it’s a place where you’ll find – today and every day – some of the bravest people you could ever meet.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am Hayley the mummy of Rhys (aged almost 5)  a few weeks ago we found out that his little bestie Ellis (age 3) had been diagnosed with neuroblastma cancer.

Ellis is currently having treatment at GOSH, and Rhys said he wanted to say thank you to the hospital for looking after Ellis whilst he was poorly.

We are holding a raffle at the end of Easter half term and also looking at other ways we can raise money.

In the meantime if you would like to make a donation it will go along way.

Rhys would love to be able to make a difference especially in these hard times during the pandemic.

charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story:
Great Ormond Street Hospital Childrens Charity (GOSH Charity) and McColls, the leading neighbourhood retailer, are delighted to announce a brand-new charity partnership that aims to raise £1million over the next three years.

Seriously ill children from across the UK travel to Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) for specialist treatment for rare and complex conditions.

The money raised by McColls will help fund GOSH Charitys vital parent accommodation service, supporting the refurbishment of 'McColl's House', which brings families closer together when a child is receiving treatment.

By partnering with GOSH Charity, McColls colleagues and customers will support families at the heart of their communities, right across the UK.

pageSummary: We the family are asking for contributions because Danny would rather help children in need.
pageSummaryWhat: We the family are asking for contributions
pageSummaryWhy: Danny would rather help children in need.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

In honour of  Danny, we are kindly asking those who wanted to buy him flowers that instead you contribute to Great Ormond Street Hospital. 

“Don’t waste your money on me” he would probably say. 

“Spend it on the kids!”

As most who new Danny, would know how much he loved his children, grandchildren, nieces and nephews. He would rather be down and dirty on the floor with the kids then sit up a table and be with adults. He was the light and laughter of any room and  made jokes in the midst of awkward moments to brighten the tone. 

If you are on this page, I don’t need to tell you what an incredible man Danny was, because you already know. He’s loved, helped and supported most he ever come to know. We all have those moments and memory’s close to our hearts, that we will cherish forever. 

We are saddened that we can not celebrate Danny’s life with you all just how he would of liked or indeed how he deserves. Once the restrictions are over, when we can all come out and get together we will most definitely celebrate in the most memorable, up beat, happy manner just as we should.

pageSummary: In memory of Marge Fryer we are fundraising
pageSummaryWhat: In memory of Marge Fryer we are fundraising
story:
Marge Fryer was a caring, beautiful person with her welcoming and loving ways. She always put everyone else before herself and worried endlessly about her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. 

With a large family of 5 children, Carol, Sandra, Ian, Peter and Neil; 11 Grandchildren Kelly, Ross, Chris, Ian, Sean, Sam, Lyndsey, Tony, Grant, Charlie and Megan; 21 Great Grandchildren she was very much loved within the family and everyone enjoyed being in her company.

She managed to touch the hearts of everyone she met and had a positive influence on those that were in her life. 

There are so many fond memories of Marge together with lots of laughable moments that will be cherished forever. 

Sadly we will have to say goodbye to our Mum and Nanny on Friday 19th March when her funeral will take place. Marge has always said she would prefer donations to flowers and in honor of her wishes we have decided to set up a fundraising page for Great Ormond Street Hospital which is a very close charity to all of our hearts with 2 of her great grandchildren currently receiving care by them.

Please donate anything possible in memory of Marge Fryer. She has done us proud over the years and we wish to do the same for her.

story:
All, 

As you have heard this week we sadly lost our beloved Paddy to cancer, there was nothing he loved more than to make people smile especially children.

For that reason rather than have flowers we are asking people to donate to GOSH in his memory. All those that knew him remember all the fund raising he has done previously for this wonderful cause. 

Due to the restrictions currently on us only a small number can attend the funeral however we will be holding a Memorial Day in his honour on July 17th where we hope to raise more money for this great charity.

Thank you for all your support and we hope to see you in July to share more paddy stories 


Love Catherine, Maggie, Sue, Jonathan, Terry, Cheryl, Mick,  Bekki and the rest of the Crilly clan 

Xx

story:
Hey, I have decided to attempt the David Goggins 4x4x48 Challenge = 4 miles, every 4 hours for 48 hours, starting Friday at 8pm.

I know it’s incredibly short notice and we’re living in difficult and uncertain times, but I’d be grateful for any support you can give to my chosen charity Great Ormond Street Children's Hospital.

Your donation will go to will go towards the seriously ill children who need Great Ormond Street Hospital for life-saving treatment every day. Every little helps so even if it's minimal, it's really appreciated.

Much love

Dave

pageSummary: Walking 75 Miles over 5 days because it is a charity very close to our hearts
pageSummaryWhy: it is a charity very close to our hearts
story:
Thank you for visiting my fundraising page.

This is a sponsored walk of 75 miles over 5 days

I have chosen to support the Olivia Hodson Cancer Fund, this is a Special Purpose Fund within Great Ormond Street Hospital Children’s Charity.

The fund was established in 1997, in memory of Olivia, who was just two and a half years old when she died from a malignant germ cell tumour.
Olivia was my husbands cousin and so this is obviously very close to our hearts.

Their work supports childhood cancer and palliative care projects at Great Ormond Street Hospital and the UCL Institute of Child Health.

Please take a few minutes to visit their website to learn more about the ground breaking projects that they support at: http://ohcf.org

pageSummary: I am walking the Cornish Coastal Footpath! because Every child deserves the best chance at life.
pageSummaryWhat: I am walking the Cornish Coastal Footpath!
pageSummaryWhy: Every child deserves the best chance at life.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

ATTENTION ALL.

I’m taking up a sponsored walk for charity. I walk a lot during working hours so feel sufficiently trained for this but it’s still going to be a massive challenge! I aim to be completely self sufficient during this time bringing only the bare essentials to keep me connected to the world so I can update you on my progress! I intend to cover approximately a 270 mile stretch of the path from Bude to Looe.

Want to join me in supporting a good cause? I'm raising money for Great Ormond Street Hospital and Children's Charity and your contribution will make an impact, whether you donate £5 or £500. Every little bit helps. Thank you for your support. I've included information about Great Ormond Street Hospital and Children's Charity below.

Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) is an international centre of excellence in child healthcare. Together with our research partner, the UCL Institute of Child Health (ICH), we form the UK’s only academic biomedical research centre specialising in paediatrics.

Since its formation in 1852, the hospital has been dedicated to children’s healthcare and to finding new and better ways to treat childhood illnesses.

Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity raises money to enable the hospital to provide world class care and to pioneer new treatments and cures for childhood illnesses.

With over 220,000 patient visits every year, we need your support to help us give hope to our young patients and their families.

charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story:
Great Ormond Street Hospital Childrens Charity (GOSH Charity) and McColls, the leading neighbourhood retailer, are delighted to announce a brand-new charity partnership that aims to raise £1million over the next three years.

Seriously ill children from across the UK travel to Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) for specialist treatment for rare and complex conditions.

The money raised by McColls will help fund GOSH Charitys vital parent accommodation service, supporting the refurbishment of 'McColl's House', which brings families closer together when a child is receiving treatment.

By partnering with GOSH Charity, McColls colleagues and customers will support families at the heart of their communities, right across the UK.

pageSummary: I am running my first marathon because I want to support this wonderful cause.
pageSummaryWhat: I am running my first marathon
pageSummaryWhy: I want to support this wonderful cause.
story:
I've always liked the idea of being able to say "I've run a marathon"......but the reality of actually doing it is something different! Through the lockdowns of the last 12 months I have started running regularly and have decided now is the time....

I would really appreciate your sponsorship support, firstly to make sure I keep going when it gets tough, and secondly (and more importantly) to raise money for the brilliant Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) which is very close to our heart.

Our daughter, Sophia, was transferred to GOSH immediately after her birth and then spent the next 3 months there, undergoing 15 operations. The team at GOSH were brilliant and I'm so pleased to say that Sophia lives a completely normal life now. 

Every single penny I raise will go to GOSH and every donation however big or small will be so gratefully received.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. pageSummary: We are climbing the three highest peaks in the UK because It is a fantastic cause which we fully support
pageSummaryWhat: We are climbing the three highest peaks in the UK
pageSummaryWhy: It is a fantastic cause which we fully support
story:
The Three Peaks | Scaling the highest peaks in England, Scotland and Wales within 24 hours in aid of Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children

On 24th April 2021 our team of 11 Mace colleagues will be embarking on a the National Three Peaks Challenge! 

This will consist of scaling the highest mountains in the United Kingdom - Ben Nevis (Scotland), Snowden (Wales) and Scafell Pike (England). The total walking distance is 23 miles with a total ascent of over 10,000 feet; we aim to complete this challenge within a 24 hour period including the 462 miles of driving in between climbs.

We are taking on this daunting challenge in aid of Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children – a worthy cause which a number of our team have personal connections to.

eventName: Lands End to John o'Groats Virtual Challenge
pageSummary: running the length of Britain because we're crazy!!!
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Over the course of 2021, Tom and I will be running the length of Britain- 874 miles- following the route of Land's End to John O'Groats.

As many of you may know, As a family we spent a lot of time to and from Great Ormond street in 2012, when Tom broke his neck. Whilst there we continuously received the most phenomenal care, both for Tom and for family support. We also know that we were fortunate to have quite a short stay at the hospital whereas many other families spend a significantly longer time there. Its for these reasons we want to dedicate this monumental challenge to the life changing team at Great Ormond Street Hospital. Thank you for everything you do ❤️

eventName: Skydive for GOSH on behalf of Isabella Hurst
pageSummary: We are skydiving from 12,000 feet because of their great care for Isabella
pageSummaryWhy: of their great care for Isabella
story:
17th April 2020 - Isabella was born and life was perfect - our family complete.

After a few weeks, we noticed something in Isabella's nose that didn't seem right. After numerous referrals from GPs and hospitals, various MRI & CT scans and sleepless nights of worrying Isabella was diagnosed with Nasal Meningoencephalocele - unfortunately her skull has not fully formed at the front, leaving a small hole and the sack protecting her brain protruding in to her nose.

Luckily this has not effected our funny, full of life baby at all - but it will require surgery to fix, with a small piece of bone to be taken from elsewhere to fill the hole.

In June 2021, a couple of months after Isabella's 1st birthday she will undergo surgery at Great Ormond Street Hospital.

To give us a way of feeling like we're doing something to help, and to thank GOSH for their fantastic, reassuring care myself and her Godfather  Josh Mann will skydive from 12,000 feet to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity.

We will be covering all costs ourselves so 100% of money raised will go directly to charity.

story: The Great North Run is the biggest half marathon in the world. Run from city to coast as the Red Arrows roar overhead. Every day brings new challenges at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH). Every day, 619 children and young people from across the UK arrive. Every day, doctors and nurses battle the most complex illnesses, and the brightest minds come together to achieve pioneering medical breakthroughs. And every day is a chance for you to make a difference. This extraordinary hospital has always depended on charitable support to give seriously ill children the best chance to fulfil their potential. A better future for seriously ill children starts here.

pageSummary: I am running the St. Albans Half Marathon because of the amazing work they do to support UK families
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the St. Albans Half Marathon
pageSummaryWhy: of the amazing work they do to support UK families
story:
One of my personal goals for 2021 is to complete the St. Albans Half Marathon on Sunday 13th June, raising money for GOSH (Great Ormond Street Hospital Charity) 

Having worked with GOSH in a professional capacity, I believe strongly in all the work they are doing for families throughout the UK.

GOSH are a charity that help families and children throughout the UK receive life changing treatment for illnesses. They provide a range of support to the children and families to ease their journey. 

Your donations can:

  • Provide family accommodation so parents and carers can stay close by while their children undergo treatment
  • Fund vital services including the hospital Play Team which help patients understand treatment and cope with separation 
  • Support social work and multi-faith chaplaincy teams who provide much needed family advice and support 

Things have become increasingly challenging for the Charity Sector in general, and more specifically for those travelling for treatment and trying to find accommodation due to the Covid-19 Pandemic.


Your support is greatly appreciated and is helping make the experience of children and families undergoing treatment so much easier, by enabling GOSH to deliver practical and emotional support.

Please donate to such an amazing cause! Check out https://www.gosh.org/ for more information on their work!

charity.description:
We are the world’s largest charity dedicated to saving lives through research.
Our vision is to bring forward the day when all cancers are cured.

Cancer Research UK is a registered charity in England and Wales (1089464), Scotland (SC041666), the Isle of Man (1103) and Jersey (247).
charity.name: Cancer Research UK
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 1089464, Scotland SC041666
pageSummary: We are a team of 18 people that work at Matalan
pageSummaryWhat: We are a team of 18 people that work at Matalan
story:
Hi. We are a team of 18 people who work at Matalan. Each year we set ourselves a challenge in support of charities. This year in aid of Cancer Research UK we have set a challenge of walking 7 million steps in the month of March. This charity is one that is close to our hearts, having myself lost both of my parents to cancer. 

Cancer survival rates have doubled over the past 40 years. Consistent progress is being made but improvements to technology and ground-breaking work offer new opportunities to find different ways to prevent, diagnose and treat cancer and improve survival rates even further. Help Cancer Research UK improve results even faster.

Cancer won’t wait. So let’s get started right now.

Can you help us? 

Your support is crucial. If you’re able, we’d love it if you could make a donation to help us achieve our mission and support Cancer Research UK.

If you can’t give, but still want to support our cause, please share our page with your friends, family members, and coworkers. With more people aware of our cause, we’ll be one step closer to reaching our goal.

The team at Matalan would like to thank you in advance for your support.

Sincerely, Mark


Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummary: Less birthday gin this year, raising funds because In Laura's memory
pageSummaryWhat: Less birthday gin this year, raising funds
story:
Approaching my 39th birthday, I've really come to realise what is truly important in life. I'm really lucky, I have a loving family, a great gin bar and good health. Though what I really wish for is to have one more moment with my dear friend Laura aka Wiggy. Through marriages, kids, jobs and families  we used to natter so much, especially in our latter years and she is a friend that cannot and will never be forgotten.

Whilst pregnant, Wiggy was diagnosed in early 2019 with triple negative breast cancer, one of the most aggressive and hardest to treat. I watched cancer devastate her pregnancy and life like a cruel joke that never gave up and Wiggy carried that demon and fought it every single day. She passed peacefully in April 2020 with her loving family by her side. 

There is nothing I can do now, apart from try and raise awareness and support to cancer research rather than my birthday, so then hopefully the future lives of others can be supported and essentially treated. All I ask of others, is that if you have a spare five quid then it would be greatly recieved into the pot and then on the 21st I can raise a glass to my beautiful friend Laura and her massive Robbo grin. 


Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

eventName: charity walk in memory of Nicholas Hurst
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On June the 9th, I am walking 35 miles in a day for Cancer Research UK.

I have decided to do this walk in memory of my stepfather, Nicholas Hurst, on what would have been his 51st birthday. He unfortunately lost his battle to pancreatic cancer last summer, three short months after his diagnosis and left behind his wife, Laura, and beautiful one year old daughter, Charlotte. 

For those of you who had the pleasure of knowing Nick, you will be aware of his passion for walking. With this in mind, I thought a charity walk would be the most appropriate way to raise money in his memory.

With all this being said, any donation to Cancer Research UK will be greatly appreciated, as funding to the charity and vital research into new potential treatments has been slowed in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. As well as individuals with a cancer diagnosis receiving little or delayed treatment despite, it still being one of the top causes of death in the UK. So, please any penny you can spare will be appreciated by many and help towards putting a stop to the suffering across the UK.

story:
I would love to raise money for Cancer Research this spring, as I would love to help gain awareness and do everything I can to help the organisation. 

This topic is quite close to me as many years ago, my mum suffered with breast cancer. She fought through and beat the disease, and I would like to raise money so that other people will be able to do the same! Cancer research conducts research about the treatment and prevention of the disease and the money raised will go to helping this research go further.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I will be running a 1/2 Marathon on April 8th to raise money for Cancer Research UK. I have decided to do this as it’s something very close to my heart as my family have been greatly affected by this horrible disease. The people closest to me will know why this is such an important cause for me. 

This is for everyone that has suffered, knows someone that has suffered, lost someone, and in memory of those that are sadly no longer with us. 

I would greatly appreciate any kind of donation no matter how small, and spreading the message to help raise as much as possible

Thank you in advance.

pageSummary: I am Cycling 1500km over a 8 week period because i want to raise money and awareness for this cause
pageSummaryWhat: I am Cycling 1500km over a 8 week period
pageSummaryWhy: i want to raise money and awareness for this cause
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Every person and family effected by cancer deserves to receive the best treatment, love and care to make sure there loved ones are as comfortable as possible when going through the hard times it brings. One day we will beat cancer.

Starting 13/03/2021. I am going to be taking on this 8 week challenge in memory of my Grandad Gerry who has sadly recently passed away from lung and liver cancer, he put up a great fight and our entire family and friends are extremely proud of him. I will be wearing a Emerald Green Ribbon and a White ribbon on each ride that signifies the 2 cancers that he was effected by.

My good friend Sam Dartmouth is going to be keeping me company and chipping in with 500KM of the grand total through cycling and running. 

Each ride will be uploaded onto this page so please follow my journey and ill see you at the finish line. 

"Plan for the worst, hope for the best and live for the moment"

THANK YOU ❤️

story:
Stanley Richard Charles Mullins

A cherished Husband, Father, Grandfather and Great
Grandfather.

Stan died peacefully on February 3rd at the age
of 91.

As a wonderful family man and homemaker he will be greatly missed by all of us. He touched many more lives during his long and successful
career in banking.

Cancer Research was a charity close to his heart should you wish to make a donation to commemorate his memory.

From the family of ‘Our Stan’

18th March 1929 – 3rd February 2021

David lost his battle to cancer in October 2020. Due to Covid restrictions we were unable to have many of our friends and family pay their respects. 

In 2016 David took part in a Cancer Research  walking trial and he walked every day right up to the day he went to hospital in September 2020.

I have taken up the challenge to walk 1600 kilometres ( 1000) miles in 2021. To date I have walked 438k.

If you would like to donate to Cancer Research at any time throughout this year I would be most grateful. 

I will keep you up to date with my progress.

In memory of David and his positive attitude I thank you.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story: I am a passionate fundraiser for Marie Curie, supporting people supporting us in Kent. Would love to be able to share my daily stories and steeps done for Marie Curie. I will do both 10.000+ steps per day and 100+ squats per day:) Wish me luck! Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Kirsty's dad Les, died last August from bowel cancer. He was cared for by Marie Curie in his final months and Kirsty said, the hospice gave us our dad back.

When dad was first diagnosed, I felt like my insides had been ripped out, it was a real gut-wrenching moment. He was a single parent and brought us up on his own, so we were all really close. Dad was a really active, sociable man and never viewed himself as an elderly person. When Marie Curie was first mentioned dad wasn't keen and I must admit I also thought that's where you go to die. But he was there for about four weeks and I can honestly say Marie Curie gave us our dad back. That was just the best thing ever - he had no distress and we knew they were taking such good care of him.
The nurses said they would let me know when they felt dad was close to the end so I could stay with him and I ended up self-isolating with him at the hospice for the last week of his life. That meant the world to me. I feel very privileged that I had

story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I will be challenging myself to run 150 km throughout April 2021 to raise money for the Marie Curie Charity. Marie Curie is an incredible organisation that has helped so many families including my own. 

This challenge is in memory of my Grandma, Dorothy Taplin and my Grandad, Patrick White. Both of my Grandparents were supported by Marie Curie in their final weeks of life and I would love to be able to show my appreciation and give something back. 

Thank you, 

Laura.

pageSummary: I am taking part in the 2 hour challenge because I want to help Marie Curie front line nurses
pageSummaryWhat: I am taking part in the 2 hour challenge
pageSummaryWhy: I want to help Marie Curie front line nurses
story:
Back in 2018 I took part in the Great North Run to raise money for Marie Curie but with so few organised events many charities are struggling to raise much needed funds and I would like to help. 

I have taken on  the Marie Curie 2 hour challenge which asks you to do something for just 2 hours.  I have chosen to run for 2 hours on St Patrick's day non-stop. 

£20 pays for a Marie Curie nurse to care for someone in their own home for 1 hour of the day. 

If you would like to support me any donation will be very much appreciated. 

THANK YOU SO MUCH 💜

Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
eventName: Kentucky Peakers with My Peak Challenge for Marie Curie
story:
Kirsty's dad Les, died last August from bowel cancer. He was cared for by Marie Curie in his final months and Kirsty said, the hospice gave us our dad back.When dad was first diagnosed, I felt like my insides had been ripped out, it was a real gut-wrenching moment. He was a single parent and brought us up on his own, so we were all really close. Dad was a really active, sociable man and never viewed himself as an elderly person. When Marie Curie was first mentioned dad wasn't keen and I must admit I also thought that's where you go to die. But he was there for about four weeks and I can honestly say Marie Curie gave us our dad back. 

Thank you for helping us help Marie Curie.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Morrisons oldest colleague, Irene is one of Marie Curie’s wonderful fundraisers. She’s been fundraising for 36 years and has spent 25 of those raising funds at  Morrisons Solihull store. Despite going through multiple cancer operations and a full hip replacement herself, at 90 years old she’s dedicated so much to raising funds for Marie Curie. 

Usually, in March Irene would be out collecting alongside other collectors for Marie Curie's Great Daffodil Appeal, however this year due to the pandemic, Irene isn't able to collect. Even though Irene can't be out with her bucket and iconic yellow hat this year, Irene still wants to raise as much as she can for Marie Curie and you can donate directly to Irene's fundraising this year through JustGiving.



Every penny you donate will m

ake a massive difference, read below to see what a difference your donations can make:


£1 puts a pen torch in the pocket of a Marie Curie Nurse or doctor, so they can do vital examinations of the people in their care.

£3 pays for heating one of our hospices for an hour, meaning the patients and their families feel warm and comfortable, even on the nippiest of days.

£5 pays for a glass of wine and a nourishing meal for a patient at one of our hospices because enjoying a favourite tipple brings a smile to peoples faces and is a treat many look forward to.

£16 is enough to sponsor a bed for an hour in one of Marie Curie's 9 Hospices across the UK meaning someone living with a terminal illness can get expert care when they need it most

Just £20 is enough to fund an hour of expert care from a Marie Curie Nurse so someone with a terminal illness can get the support they need in the comfort of their own home.

£32 pays for a call to the Marie Curie Support Line, meaning someone in need can  pick up the phone  and receive practical information and  emotional support

story:
The Great Daffodil Appeal is Marie Curie's biggest annual fundraising campaign. 

Every March, millions of people across the UK support this fundraising event by giving a small donation to wear a daffodil pin. This makes it one of the UK’s most recognisable charity appeals.

 Money raised through the appeal helps Marie Curie provide free care and support to people living with a terminal illnesses.

pageSummary: To run 4 miles, every 4 hours, for 48 hours 5/3/21 because front-line nursing and hospice care needs our help
pageSummaryWhat: To run 4 miles, every 4 hours, for 48 hours 5/3/21
pageSummaryWhy: front-line nursing and hospice care needs our help
story:
I (Sarah) and my running buddy Louise, aim to run four miles (6.4K) every four hours for 48 hours: This challenge will push us mentally and physically. No longer will it be running for fun, instead we are running for purpose, so please support us on this journey.

We have all lost loved ones lately, or we know people who have. Receiving professional end of life care is important to each and every one of us. 

Marie Curie is a leading UK charity that is operating on the front lines.

I have chosen to support the Marie Curie Charity, which has been helpful to my family in recent months. Sadly, upon loosing two very special members of our family within the month of February 2021 we would like to invite you to support us with giving something back. 

With your help we will stay motivated and complete all, or as much of this challenge as best we can!

Thanks for taking the time to visit my page,

Sarah

eventName: Marie Curie West Berkshire Great Daffodil Appeal Virtual Collection
pageSummary: Looking for donations because we were looking forward to collecting in person!
pageSummaryWhy: we were looking forward to collecting in person!
story:
This time of year heralds the coming of spring, with new growth and an abundance of colour.  Usually Marie Curie fundraisers all over the country allow you to show your support by brightening your lapel with a daffodil.  

Unfortunately, the decision has been made that our fundraisers won't be on the streets, sharing their smiles and hearing your stories.  So we're looking to your generosity to help us keep our nurses providing support to those in need of their help.

Our target
To put our target in context, a Marie Curie nurse costs £20 an hour, so if we reach our target we will cover the cost of a nurse for 5, 8 hour shifts.  Reaching half of our target pays for the running of a coordination centre for a day, and doubling our target allows us to train 3 nurses to provide the knowledge they need.

About Marie Curie

Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in peoples homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.

pageSummary: We are hoping in memory of mum to raise money because they provided care and support to the whole family
pageSummaryWhat: We are hoping in memory of mum to raise money
pageSummaryWhy: they provided care and support to the whole family
story:
Our mum Sylvia had a short, often very painful and sickening fight with Cholangiocarcinoma or bile duct cancer. A rare and unfortunately very aggressive cancer that is virtually always fatal in a very short period of time. 

From diagnosis to mums passing was less than 8 weeks and still seems quite surreal, although we were beside her as much as we could be and were with her and other family members when she left us to be with our dearest deeply missed dad Kenneth. 

The support from the district nurses, doctors and medical team were fab but supported by our wonderful NHS.

Marie Curie nurses offered mum and us the family care, compassion and time to recharge and to continue our care for mum, when we needed it most. Their work is funded by donations and is a vital resource; we would love others to have the opportunity to receive if they need it which is why this page exists. 

Please consider giving what you can in memory of a much loved Mum, Sister, Mother-in-law, Godmother, Aunty Sylvie and friend.

Thank you in advance from us all

story:

Marie Curie charity cannot support their Great Daffodil Appeal fundraising in the usual way of public collections during March this year, so we've decided to take up their challenge, mix it up, and find a different way!  Alice and myself have thrown ourselves into baking and are preparing take-away baking boxes with the hope of delighting friends and family in and around Linlithgow on Friday 26th March, and hopefully generating lots of donations to this fantastic charity.  We are hoping to maximise the use of gift-aid where possible, and cannot charge for the baking we are producing, but would like to offer the opportunity to make a donation to this supportive charity.

Our Marie Curie nurse came to our family home the night before mum was taken into hospital. Having a Marie curie nurse with mum on her last night at home took away mums Anxiety and gave mum the comfort she needed,  and gave dad some much needed respite and peace that night, Mum was taken into hospital the next day , Dad  My brother tony and I stayed with mum round the clock until she passed aged 74 with Lung cancer, We will never forget that Marie curie nurse, true Angel's.

For the past 4 years I have helped raise money for this wonderful charity, please could you sponsor me and help other families get the help, care, and comfort our family received from the true life Angel's 

  Thank you so much 

          Kim xxxxxx

story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

We are raising money for Marie Curie in recognition of their National Day of Reflection on 23rd March 2021, the anniversary of the first lockdown.

This day is being held to reflect on our collective loss, support those who've been bereaved, and hope for a brighter future.

This annual day will give us all time to pause and think about this unprecedented loss and support each other through our grief.

pageSummaryWhat: Sarah & Teddy, Marie & Ollie: Walk 100k challenge
pageSummaryWhy: We all know someone with cancer
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Sarah and Marie are setting off with Teddy & Ollie. Making walkie’s count for Marie Curie. We will be clocking up the kilometres round Newburgh and the Leeds Liverpool canal in memory of our loved ones. We are challenging our legs to 100km. Please help by donating to Marie Curie nurses.

Sarah: both my parents died from cancer and I’m dedicating this challenge to them. When mum was nursed at home, Marie curie nurses sat with her all night so that she was never alone in her final days offering support both to my mum and the family.

Marie: my friend Bernie Birch sadly died 6 yrs ago with ovarian cancer. A friend who gave so much and was taken too soon. We shared  a lot of good times with laughter  and she can never be replaced. Bernie had a Marie Curie nurse who was also her best friend from school. I’m doing this for you Bernie xx

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Marie Curie
eventName: Archie and Milo step up, squat down and share kindness for Marie Curie
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page

Due to the devestating losses Marie Curie have encountered since the start of the pandemic, my little brother and I would like to help make a difference. March is the start of Marie Curies well known and supported Great Daffodil Appeal, this year because they aren’t able to fundraise in the normal way, they have asked people to take on different challenges to help raise vital funds. We want to take on them ALL. During March we will be Stepping into Spring with 10,000 steps a day, challenging ourselves to 3000 squats, taking on a two hour fitness challenge and we will also be sharing kindness to our friends family and neighbours by delivering daffodils and window display cards to those people who would like to support Marie Curie from the comfort of their own home.  If you would like to receive a daffodil and a window card please just send us a message and we would love to come and deliver one to you either personally or by post. It doesn’t matter how big or small the donation may be as every penny really does count. The charity provided over 66,000 hours of direct nursing care last year,to people living with a terminal illness in the North East and we would like to do something to help such a worthy cause. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

eventName: Raising funds for Marie Curie during 2021
pageSummary: Peakers England are raising funds because of the support they give in times of great need.
pageSummaryWhy: of the support they give in times of great need.
story:
Kirsty's dad Les, died last August from bowel cancer. He was cared for by Marie Curie in his final months and Kirsty said, the hospice gave us our dad back.

When dad was first diagnosed, I felt like my insides had been ripped out, it was a real gut-wrenching moment. He was a single parent and brought us up on his own, so we were all really close. Dad was a really active, sociable man and never viewed himself as an elderly person. When Marie Curie was first mentioned dad wasn't keen and I must admit I also thought that's where you go to die. But he was there for about four weeks and I can honestly say Marie Curie gave us our dad back. That was just the best thing ever - he had no distress and we knew they were taking such good care of him.
The nurses said they would let me know when they felt dad was close to the end so I could stay with him and I ended up self-isolating with him at the hospice for the last week of his life. That meant the world to me. I feel very privileged that I had

pageSummary: The children of Smisby Day Nursery because as a nursery community we would like to give back.
pageSummaryWhat: The children of Smisby Day Nursery
pageSummaryWhy: as a nursery community we would like to give back.
story:
As part of our ongoing support to charities the staff and children of Smisby Day Nursery have chosen to fund raise for Marie Curie and their great daffodil appeal 2021. 

On Wednesday 24th March 2021 the children are going to be dressing in yellow for the day, going on a daffodil doddle and treasure hunt around the village where our community will be displaying daffodil pictures for the children to find.  They will be leaving daffodils on doorsteps as a random act of kindness too.

We will be holding a raffle for a Marie Curie themed cake and a luxury hamper on the day and taking part in lots of fun activities with the children.  

We do hope you will get behind us to raise as much money as we can for this lovely charity.  As our little ones start out their lives it is lovely to teach them how to help others who are at the end of theirs and Marie Curie provide wonderful support and care to people and their families at that sad time.

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Usually, I would spend my birthday knee deep in daffodils as part of Marie Curie’s biggest fundraising campaign, the Great Daffodil Appeal.

Like many fundraising events, we’ve had to cancel the collections this Spring due to the pandemic but the need for funds continues. 

So, since I can’t collect on my birthday and I can’t go out to celebrate, please think about buying me a birthday drink here instead! My favourite tipple, a glass of white wine, in my favourite Swan Tavern costs £4.50 but feel free to ‘buy’ yourself whatever you fancy too! :-)

It is 10 years this year since the Linlithgow Marie Curie Fundraising Group was set up and I joined as their first Secretary. I loved it so much that fundraising has become my career so I wanted to mark that milestone and honour the important part the group played in my life by fundraising for them on my birthday.

Thank you for your support which means the world to me and all the families supported by Marie Curie.

Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in peoples homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.

story:
We at Little Delwood Kindergarten are proud to announce that throughout the month of March, we will be fundraising for the Marie Curie Chandler's Ford Group (a charity providing care and support for terminally ill patients), by taking our Kindergarten children on a weekly walk or 'Daffodil Doddle' to keep active, raise money, and look for flowers in our surrounding areas!

We hope to keep you updated with pictures of our progress as the month continues! We welcome any and all support and donations that you can offer us. Thank you everyone!

Marie Curie Charity provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Their nurses work night and day in peoples homes and our hospices offer specialist care. They also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.

"During the difficult last year our nurses, hospices and Support Line have been here through it all, day and night, seven days a week, caring for people with and without coronavirus. We never stopped. Right now, more people need us than ever before." - The Marie Curie Charity

pageSummary: This is for the Village of Hartest because of COVID we cant hold a real coffee morning!
pageSummaryWhat: This is for the Village of Hartest
pageSummaryWhy: of COVID we cant hold a real coffee morning!
story:
MARIE CURIE CANCER CARE  

In 1993 we commenced coffee mornings in the Village in aid of Marie Curie Cancer Care. These were firstly held at my home and garden and then moved into in the Institute because it became a very popular event! There has only been one year when this was not possible to meet and that was in 2002 when the Hall was being
renovated. 

The generosity and support over the years has been quite incredible.
Over the time we have raised £9,017. How exciting it will be when we reach £10,000 ! I didn’t want COVID19 to stop us this year so with the help of our local organizer I have set up this JustGiving page in case you would like to continue to donate to this worthy cause and have your coffee in the confines of your own home !  If you would prefer to give a gift direct to me please place in my postbox, and I will forward it for you. For further information, I can be contacted on 01284 830268 or at jpasque@aol.com Thankyou for your continued support. Keep safe. 

Jo Pask

eventName: Ro's Winchester Fundraising Group Great Daffodil Appeal Virtual Collection
pageSummary: I am collecting because their services are needed more than ever.
pageSummaryWhy: their services are needed more than ever.
story:
I've been fundraising for Marie Curie ever since my Mum died 10  years ago. Most years I've spent a couple of hours wearing a big yellow hat and standing on a high street with a collection bucket and handing out those little daffodil pins. It's surprisingly good fun!

More recently I've joined my local fundraising group helping with events (love a cake sale...) and organising daffodil collection boxes in shops, cafes, pubs etc. But that's not possible this year and the collection is mostly virtual. So if you would normally support Marie Curie at this time of year and are looking for a way to do so, please consider donating :-)

Daffodils are pretty special to me as my Mum would always get me some on my birthday - apparently there were lots of them when I was born. She was also a nurse and the nursing care that Marie Curie provides can allow people with terminal illness to stay in their own homes, by caring for them and supporting their
families. This is something I support whole-heartedly.

There's lots of info on their website www.mariecurie.org.uk, but in case it is useful to anyone reading this, I'll highlight their increased telephone support lines, including bereavement support (no matter whether expected or unexpected) www.mariecurie.org.uk/help/support/marie-curie-support-line. 


Thank you!

pageSummary: Raising money for the Great Daffodil Appeal because they helped care for my Dad in his hours of need.
pageSummaryWhat: Raising money for the Great Daffodil Appeal
pageSummaryWhy: they helped care for my Dad in his hours of need.
story:
Hello I'm Annie and this is a story I'd appreciate massively if you could take the time to read😁

I know the days, weeks, months etc. have been hard, miserable and dull recently, but they are starting to get brighter(yippy)😁🔆

My life turned very dull to say the least on 18th July 2020 when my brave Dad Roger was suddenly taken from us after being diagnosed with cancer on the 27th June 2020. 

We never expected in a million years this would be the outcome of a small back ache he had been experiencing for a couple of weeks. He was so fit, healthy and active. This came out of nowhere and smashed our world into pieces.

He was diagnosed and then died 3 weeks later. He was ever so brave and dignified after receiving such news. I was in awe of him even more than ever. Having to process that my Dad who was my everything was going to die imminently and then watch this happen is indescribable, but how he took this news on the chin was just incredible. The first thing he did after being told this news was worry about us and how we were. That's who he was, an incredibly special, caring man. 

For anyone who knew my Dad they knew he was someone who would help out anyone and put everyone before himself. 

The the only help left for Dad and us were the amazing and invaluable Marie Curie nurses. 
Marie Curie nurses brought some wonderful brightness back into our darkest moments while my Dad was dying and the care they provided him was 2nd to none during some of the most unprecedented times we have all recently experienced and I know they are doing this daily for so many others who have a terminal illness.
They really are Earths angels.😇
They are so important and I know you don't ever think of these organisations until you need them and that's totally understandable. I was one of these people.
This is why I'm showing my support for them now with their Great Daffodil Appeal which had been very different this year due to current restrictions. 

I'm currently trying to raise awareness for them as they are in desperate need like alot of other charities at the moment and this one is obviously close to my heart.
Marie Curie offer so much support to people with terminal illness. Care at home, hospice care, bereavement councilling it's endless.

I have a few boxes of beautiful daffodils pin badges(35 in a box) which have been provided to me by Marie Curie. Obviously at present, times are very different and restricted. I have created this page so anyone who would like a daffodil but cannot get one physically can purchase a virtual one by making a small donation to show support even if they are unable to obtain a daffodil pin badge. If anyone would like to give a donation for a virtual Daffodil pin badge then the suggested amount is £1. For every box of daffodil pin badges sold it will provide just over an hours care for someone with a terminal illness. 

Please contact me or Mike if you would like a daffodil pin badge physically, as delivery may be possible in the local area. 

There have been alot people like me who have lost people they love so dearly, especially in 2020/21 and its been very hard and different for everyone who has during this time but without organisations like Marie Curie, times would be a lot, lot harder. 

Thankyou for taking the time to read this and thanks for your support. 

Annie :) xx

pageSummary: We are taking on the 2 hour challenge because the help we received when my mother passed away.
pageSummaryWhat: We are taking on the 2 hour challenge
pageSummaryWhy: the help we received when my mother passed away.
story:
We as a family are taking part in the 2 hour challenge for Marie Curie, as a way to thank them for their impecable care the night my mum passed away. We will be spending 2 hours gaming with each other (online socially distanced)


As most of you already know my mum Anne passed away in 2020 after a couragious battle with cancer. Which is currently coming up on 12 months. We have picked Mothers Day to do our challenge as we feel like thats the best way to mark the day when the most important person cant be with us.

Mum passed away at home surrounded by her family, the night she passed we were greeted with two Marie Curie nurses at 5am, who came to pronouce her death. The care, thought and respect they gave us as a family and mum was impecable. They went above and beyond to wash, change and make my mum look like my mum which ill be forever grateful for. I could never thank them enough and im sure they take this care with everyones loved ones not just ours.

Covid has been difficult for everyone of us far and wide but its so important that services like this receive all the help they can because their help at someones worst time is invaluable. We will never be able to thank them enough. for 2 hours of our time doing something as a family we enjoy its nothing.

Thank You

Denise, Matt, Simon, Lucas and LLinos x

charity.name: Marie Curie
eventName: In memory of James Alfred Rozier
story:
Beloved husband, father, brother, grandfather and great-grandfather James Alfred Rozier passed away suddenly in the morning of Friday 5th March 2021. 

His funeral will be held at Telford Crematorium at 5.30pm on the 22nd March 2021. We’d love this to be an open invitation, but unfortunately due to Covid restrictions this isn’t possible. 

It was James’ express wishes that rather than flowers be sent, he would prefer instead that a donation be made to Marie Curie in his memory. 

His passions were football, dancing and he loved the garden. 

He was a gentle and kind man, quiet and disarming with the warmest smile - and if you needed help, he’d be by your side in a heartbeat.  

Hopefully these funds help others in the way that he helped all of us.
