charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Through this challenging time, we all thought that we could reach out and make a difference through making a change by organising an event that would bring us all together in our local community. We plan on hosting a football match between ourselves to be played between August – September dependant on the ruling from the government over the summer break. As the pandemic got the better of us playing the match last year, we decided to restart and plan for this year as the restrictions would be reduced. We would like to support two charities that are close to our hearts that both got to extraordinary measures to make a difference to people’s lives. We chose Marie Curie and Campaign Against Living Miserably (CALM), as the two charities which all the fund we raise will go to.

Marie Curie are a charity organisation that offer care and support through terminal illness. Marie Curie Nurses and frontline staff are needed more than ever to provide vital care, expertise and compassion to dying people and their families, in their homes and our hospices across the UK, especially due to the current pandemic. They rely on the generosity of the public to deliver care. They face a devastating loss of funds. Volunteers are unable to collect on the streets, fundraising events and community activities have been cancelled or postponed and charity shops are having to close. Personally, this has affected me through the loss of my grandad last year during the pandemic. Being told he had oesophagus cancer that was terminal and being given a period of time to live was like a hole to the heart. Without the help of the palliative care team, the time would have been increasingly more difficult and much more painful. If it wasn’t for the generosity, of the public giving and the nurses staying the night, it may have become unbearable. Through donations, you could provide hours of nursing support, an evening's care or even comfort someone who is living with a terminal illness.

On the other hand, CALM is a leading movement against suicide and mental health. Every week 125 people in the UK take their own lives and 75% of all UK suicides are male. CALM exists to change this. They run this movement in three different ways: Frontline Services, Communities and Campaigns. This is all free and confidential, 7 hours a day, 7 hours a week, for anybody who needs to talk about their life problems, whether being their own or someone else’s that they are concerned about. By spreading the message, we feel it will help more people get the help or advice that they need, from whatever aspect. There's no need to hide or feel embarrassed about any life issue and through this it would help anybody out there. Through a personal experience, I know the feeling of what happens after suicide and that it shouldn’t be taken as a joke or something to be kept quiet. It takes away someone and rips a family apart, as they always hold a strong part in someone’s life. To see how staggering the figure is every week, is heart-breaking, and we feel that there are ways in which this could be reduced and eased through any difficult time especially in the current climate of the pandemic.

On behalf of Chris and Alec, we would like to raise awareness for both charities and movements. Please donate as much or as little as you can, as both of these charities have made a personal impact on us on our own troubling times. If anybody would like to support us in organising this, or come and see the match when available, please get in touch through the following links.

Instagram:

Chris
- https://www.instagram.com/cp__19/

Alec
- https://www.instagram.com/awolffr/

Please
use the following links to have a look at the amazing work each charity does:

Marie Curie 

- https://www.mariecurie.org.uk/

CALM 

- https://www.thecalmzone.net/

Thank you for your time and donations, it is greatly appreciated.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
On the 23rd March Marie Curie will be holding a National Day of Reflection to mark the year anniversary since the first national lockdown and we want to use this day to remember any loved ones that have been lost. 

£20 covers an hour of Marie Curie nursing care and for every £20 donated New Covent Garden Flower Market together with florist Shane Connolly will provide a bunch of British grown daffodils to a London based key worker as a thank you for all their amazing efforts since the start of the pandemic. 

Shane Connolly who holds a Royal Warrant of Appointment to both HM The Queen and HRH The Prince of Wales has said that ‘Marie Curie Nurses supported my beloved father and mother in the last weeks of each of their lives, in 1999 and 2005. They gave them serenity and dignity and helped make their passing so much more
peaceful and beautiful. I will be eternally grateful.’

Rebecca Barrett of New Covent Garden Market said ‘We are delighted to support Marie Curie’s National Day of Reflection and to be able to our show gratitude to key workers while raising essential funds for Marie Curie.’

The Marie Curie Nurses, both in their hospices and out in the community have been continuing to support anyone affected by a terminal illness as well as supporting their friends and families.

They still urgently need support. It is crucial a charity like Marie Curie is there for the people who need them, those living with illnesses including cancer, dementia and motor neurone disease. They are also
now directly supporting patients with coronavirus and ensuring that all their Nurses and Healthcare Assistants have sufficient PPE to keep themselves and their patients safe.

There is an increased need for Marie Curie’s services, and it is vital they can continue to be there and working in the best way for the
people who need them most.

*New Covent Garden Market are donating £2,000 of daffodils for key workers, thereafter any donations will continue to provide vital funds to help Marie Curie support anyone with a terminal illness.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Thanks for giving to dad's JustGiving page for Marie Curie.

When dad took a turn for the worse and mum and I didn't know what to do and how to cope over night with what he was going through, Marie Curie nurses came to the house, sat with him, looked after him and cared for him while we got a few hours rest.  They made a massive difference to him and us over the those few weeks at home.

Dad was always a practical type of guy!  So instead of sending us flowers etc, we'd like it if you would put some money towards helping others access the services of Marie Curie, like we did when we did, so that when someone else is their hour of need, they get the same fantastic levels of support and compassion that we did.

We've not set a target amount for the page as mum and I don't think that's right in this situation, so we'd be grateful for whatever you can give while the page is live as it will expire at the end of April.

pageSummaryWhat: In loving memory of Diane we are raising money
pageSummaryWhy: of the need for more palliative care nurses.
story:
In loving memory of Diane Claudette Straight who died peacefully on 5 March 2021 at the age of 88 years with her family by her side in her own home.

As a family we have witnessed that there is a desperate need for more palliative care resources in the community.  Marie Curie are already doing amazing work to try to ensure that people can pass away in their own homes and provide support to their loved ones.  A donation to this charity, however big or small, would be the perfect way to remember Diane who was so loved by us all.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. story:
Covid-19 has left a lot of people isolated and away from their loved ones, particularly terminally ill people, which is why Marie curie is so important. The Marie Curie frontline healthcare workers provide amazing care and support to patients and their loved ones to give them the very best end to their lives which I think is such a beautiful thing. We decided to do this walk and donate the money we raise to this charity so that Marie Curie can continue to provide the inspiring support it always has!

Adams story: My Nan was a Marie curie nurse who provided palliative care for patients, she unfortunately had to retire when she became ill with cancer herself. It would be really great to raise some money so we can give back to such an incredible charity.

story:
In loving memory of Jess Brown, 1932 - 2021. Jess passed away at home surrounded by her family on Saturday 27th February. She lived a full and fruitful life, her kindness, generosity and compassion can be an inspiration to us all.

During her short illness with leukaemia she was cared for by the Marie Curie hospice where they were so friendly and caring giving Jess and her family much needed support. Her family can’t thank them enough and would be grateful for any donations to such a worthy cause hoping Marie Curie can continue to help other families.

Jess will be sadly missed by all her family and friends.

story:
Hi All

Sadly last year we lost our mum along with many thousands more losing their loved ones. A year ago this month March this pandemic took a lot of lives and never gave families a chance to be with their loved ones in their final days or to say goodbye. This charity helps people a lot of people and now more than ever they need our support.

On the 23rd March 2021 they will hold a "Moment of Recollection" ,     a minutes silence for the lost ones at midday then at 8pm hold a light outside your home in memory of all who have gone. Even daffodils on your windowsill to symbolise Marie Curie support.

My Mum always supported this charity and hopefully you can give a little no matter how small.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Hi I thought I would set up this page as we usually collect this time of year in Fivemiletown street for our 🌼 daffodil appeal.

I have been involved with both nursing and fundraising for Marie curie for over 8 years and see 1st hand how much needed Marie curie nurses are in patients last few days.

We nurse not only cancer patients but any patients that have a terminal illness..

I remember a family saying to me as I  ended  a  night shift “ you enter a stranger and leave in the morning a friend “.💕

It’s often in the middle of the night we find patients can talk or express their symptoms/or worries etc .


Thanking you all in advance, below is some information too .


Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in peoples homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
The Marie Curie Bradford Hospice supports people living with a terminal illness and those closest to them to live as well as possible.  

The Hospice is often very different from what people expect  it is a warm, friendly space with beautiful gardens, delicious home-cooked food and personalised care. Every person is treated as an individual and helped to reach their goals and fulfil their wishes. A team of nurses, doctors, social workers, physiotherapists, chaplains, bereavement counsellors and pharmacists work together, putting every person at the centre of their care.  

Throughout Covid-19 Bradford Hospice teams have been working around the clock to continue supporting local people. Death, dying and bereavement is at the forefront of peoples minds and Marie Curie knows what a difference the right care at the end of life can make.  
 
They cant do any of this without your support. Thank you for your generous donation which supports the Bradford Hospice and Marie Curie care

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
"Take care" when crossing the road. "Take care" when swimming. "Take care" when doing seemingly anything.

In recent months and years, it became clear that "take care" was my father's motto.

Long ago, I rolled my eyes at what sometimes seemed like an excess of care. But I now know it is a mark of his love that, by instilling it, he created an environment in which my mother and I were free from harm, protected - cared for.

Despite the statistics, I never expected that cancer would affect my family.

When daddy's condition worsened, Marie Curie was on hand to provide care.

He didn't always want that help. I did my best to navigate my father's varying appetite for the abundance of support that was offered to him, whilst also caring for him to the best of my own abilities.

But, when it was clearly necessary, Marie Curie staff's assistance was incredibly welcome.

They provided twice-daily visits and became kind, familiar faces in our home, even as they journeyed to perform the same task in homes across the county. Along the journey, we learned so much from their expertise.

Marie Curie's support was invaluable in ensuring that we and daddy were able to fulfil the wish to spend his last days in his own home.

The charity's marvellous overnight care service allowed my mother and I to gain much-needed rest, and helped us to navigate the most difficult periods.

Please consider supporting Marie Curie so that more families can similarly benefit.

And, please, "take care".

pageSummaryWhat: I am going to complete a two hour dance With Rose.
pageSummaryWhy: I want us to raise money For this wonderful Cause
story:
At the Marie Curie Hospice, Liverpool, we give expert care to people with a terminal illness, and their loved ones every day of the year. Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by local people who freely volunteer their time and energy to help us run the hospice.

As well as being a place where people can stay to get the expert care they need in a friendly and homely setting, we also support people visiting with clinics and therapies. These include yoga, exercise classes and relaxation. People using the day unit can also get together over a freshly cooked lunch from our chefs.

Relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish to. 

We need to raise £6,397 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in in Liverpool, get the care and support they need.

story: I am walking in memory of Paul Cupples who was a family member - we have grandchildren in common -  Sarah (9), Matthew ( 7) and Peter (4) whose parents are my daughter Victoria and my son in law Jonathan.  The children completed a challenge during lockdown in the Spring and raised £3000  for the charity. Paul was a day hospice patient in Marie Curie and towards the end of his life had our Marie Curie nurses care for him at home. As a chaplain in the hospice I see first-hand the work being done to support those with terminal illness and the great support given to their families at a very difficult time.

pageSummary: I am running the london marathon in memory of Nick because the end of life care they gave him was everything
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the london marathon in memory of Nick
pageSummaryWhy: the end of life care they gave him was everything
story:
24 hours ago we lost Nick to cancer. 

A melanoma spread through his body and brain in less than a year . He tried hard to beat it but when he knew he couldn’t it was Marie Curie and the exceptional women - healthcare assistants and nurses who cared for him, listened to his stories, laughed at his rubbish jokes and preserved his dignity.  They also preserved my sanity .

Wendy and Sue this is for you - the unsung heroes who care for people in the most exceptional way - with levity and kindness, humour and integrity .

Nick wanted to honour you in his death and I will probably finish myself off running another Marathon (I haven’t run since the last one two years ago)..

Don’t send flowers or tears, send a donation, however small to a charity who you will need one day and who is powered by ordinary women doing miraculous things 

Thank you.

Nick, this is for you.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In the last few days of my grandad's life, Marie Curie were an amazing support system for our family. They had someone stay by his side during the night, so that he was always comfortable and it meant he could spend his last few days at home, where he's lived for the past 50 years. 

The people we spoke to couldn't have been kinder to us and they even sent a card to the family after his passing. We would love to do whatever we can to help support this wonderful charity.

Gizzen Briggs always look forward to supporting Marie Curie every year by playing in the Eastgate Centre in Inverness. Their first appeal was back in 2006. charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
As you may know I've been collecting for the Marie Curie's Great Daffodil Appeal for a few years in memory of my dad who died of aggressive prostate cancer in 2005.

When a Marie Curie nurse came to sit by his bedside so my mum could rest it was the first time i had heard of Marie Curie nurses . They rely on charity donations as they don't get any government funding.
£20 will pay for an hour of their time. £160 for an 8 hour shift approx.

Since im not able to collect in my neighbourhood as usual due to covid restrictions im taking part in this virtual appeal .

Please help support their vital work by making any size donation on this page.
Your help really does mean the world to thousands of people living with any terminal illness during these difficult times.

Thank-you

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am going to take on the Peak District challenge where I will hike 18 kilometres through the Peak District on the 24th of July in aid of Marie Curie cancer care. I will be taking on the Lathkill Loop trail which dives into the steep-sided gulley of the Lathkill Reserve and follows the River Bradford before cutting across the rolling fields back towards Monyash.

Marie curie provide vital care to cancer patients in their own homes and in hospices. £180 pays for someone with a terminal illness to attend a day therapy unit at a Marie Curie hospice. Anything that you are able to donate would be a great help to the charity, thank you for your support!

story:
Hello! Thank you so much for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

This year, I have decided to take part in the Great North Run for the very first time! My legs are already beginning to resemble jelly...

I'm running for Marie Curie because I know how the kind and supportive end-of-life care that they provide can have the most profound impact for families who have lost or are losing a loved one. 

This priceless care and support was essential even before the Coronavirus Pandemic; there are now so many more people who have been suddenly affected by the loss of friends and family members, and who are in need of support. Marie Curie have been at the forefront of this from the word go and I want to do something to show them just how appreciated they are for all that they do in both these unprecedented times and long before.

So in September I will be running the 13.1 miles that make up the unparalleled Great North Run in their name. If you would like to support me and are able to spare anything to go towards this remarkable charity, it really would mean the absolute world to me.

Newcastle, here I come! x

story:

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

I am challenging myself throughout March to walk over 100 miles and have chosen to fundraise for Marie Curie, a charity very close to my heart. Every March as we see the signs of spring, Marie Curie has traditionally fundraised through daffodil collections. This year due to the pandemic they are unfortunately unable to do so. As the weather improves and the flowers start to bloom, I will be taking myself outdoors on a daily walk to accomplish 100 miles over the month of March. While I walk I will be appreciating the change of seasons and the great work they do in our local area and hoping to reach a goal of GBP500 for the charity.

Thank You for your support and happy Spring to you all.

pageSummary: I am raising money in memory of my Grandma because they were part of her last few months xXx
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising money in memory of my Grandma
pageSummaryWhy: they were part of her last few months xXx
story:
All of you know how important my Grandma was to me and my family. She was a great lady who left a lasting impression on all those who knew her. During her last few months Marie Curie would come in of a night time every so often to allow my Mum and Aunty to have a full nights sleep. They were living with her to care for her until the very end. 

Every day off I have this month I will spend 2 hours doing a different activity, including tidying my room and a sponsored silence (wish me luck there!) If you’re on Facebook go and find my page where I will post live videos and updates every time I do a different challenge xXx

eventName: In memory of ALAN JOSEPH Mcshane
story: In memory of Alan Joseph McShane - Alan passed away at Marie Curie Hospice , Woolton on Sunday 28 February 2021. Alan's wife Barbara, his immediate and extended family,  together with his friends and colleagues, would like to show their appreciation for the comfort and care shown by the entire staff of Marie Curie to Alan. Their compassion has helped Alan to deal with his illness over the past three years, and helped him enjoy life to the full. We are all extremely grateful for this. Rather than send flowers the family would suggest donations to be given via this page directly to Marie Curie Hospice, Woolton.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Step into Spring
Take 10,000 steps every day﻿

Want to start getting active this spring? Well you’ve come to the right place!

Even in lockdown, it’s something we can do from the comfort of your own home if needs be. For example, you could walk on the spot while you watch TV or go up and down the stairs to get those steps in!

Marie Curie Nurses and hospices have been working tirelessly throughout the pandemic, providing vital care and support, and a listening ear to people in need. They can’t keep doing this without support though. And that’s where you step in. Step into Spring is a fantastic way to support Marie Curie in a safe, distanced way.

﻿

charity.name: Marie Curie
pageSummary: 10000 because Set your fitness goal (310,000 steps - 10,000 a...
pageSummaryWhy: Set your fitness goal (310,000 steps - 10,000 a...
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
At the Marie Curie Hospice, Liverpool, we give expert care to people with a terminal illness, and their loved ones every day of the year. Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by local people who freely volunteer their time and energy to help us run the hospice.

As well as being a place where people can stay to get the expert care they need in a friendly and homely setting, we also support people visiting with clinics and therapies. These include yoga, exercise classes and relaxation. People using the day unit can also get together over a freshly cooked lunch from our chefs.

Relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish to. 

We need to raise £6,397 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in in Liverpool, get the care and support they need.

Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
This month we will be supporting Marie Curie and the Great Daffodil Appeal to help ensure that families affected by terminal illness won’t be on their own; they'll have a Marie Curie Nurse alongside them to lighten their load, share their challenges and help them to face what lies ahead.

The Great Daffodil Appeal means even more in 2021 than previous years. Marie Curie Nurses have been on the front line of the pandemic providing vital care for dying people and their loved ones. At the same time, Marie Curie have been unable to fundraise as normal; this essential care provision is supported only by private and corporate donations, making our efforts so meaningful to the lives of so many.

Marie Curie Nurses provide highly skilled care in both hospices and in people’s homes across the UK, day and night:

£20 – pays for one hour of vital nursing care at home for someone living with a terminal illness

£90 – funds half an evening’s care in a person’s home when they need it most

£180 – provides nine hours of nursing support in someone’s home through the night bringing the expert care and comfort families need

£400 – pays for 24 hour stay in a Marie Curie Hospice

£1,250 pays for a portable oxygen system that will relieve distressing symptoms, so a person doesn’t have to be confined to bed

We will be hosting a Virtual Coffee Morning including:

  • 1 year Lockdown Quiz - £2 to enter
  • Lucky Daffodil - £2 to enter

Prizes:

  • Lockdown Quiz winner - Afternoon Tea delivered to your home
  • Lucky Daffodil - Afternoon Tea delivered to your home

pageSummary: Doing a virtual raffle for all who donate because Different way to remember my dad on his birthday
pageSummaryWhat: Doing a virtual raffle for all who donate
pageSummaryWhy: Different way to remember my dad on his birthday
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. This year, exactly one year after the start of the first lockdown Marie Curie are having a day of rememberance and reflection for all those through the world who has tragically last their life during a year like no other to this awful illness. It is also my dads birthday on March 23rd so what better way to be honouring my dad and remembering those near and far no matter how many years have past don't seem to long ago he was standing at his gate greeting everyone by always smiling at all. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Ripley Court Nursery will be taking part in a Daffodil Doddle to raise money for Marie Curie.

Key workers have been working tirelessly throughout the pandemic and the Marie Curie hospices, nurses and support line are amongst them!

We have chosen to walk on Tuesday 23rd March as this is the Marie Curie National Day of Reflection. All the children will take a walk, skip and run around the school grounds and the neighbouring woods wearing our handmade daffodil garlands and trying to spot as many different spring flowers as we can.

eventName: Metrobank Solihull walk the length of the UK
pageSummary: We will walk the length of the UK in a month
pageSummaryWhat: We will walk the length of the UK in a month
story:
Our Solihull Hospice has been caring for local people since 1965.Its a warm and welcoming place where we give expert care to people with a terminal illness, and their loved ones, every day of the year. Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by over 200 volunteers who play a vital role in the running of the hospice.We have a 24-bed in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish.Our out-patient unit offers clinics, therapies and group sessions and freshly cooked lunches made by our chefs. We also support carers and families, including children, with practical advice, counselling and bereavement support groups.We need to raise £9,600 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in Solihull get the care and support they need.

The Metrobank Solihull store team will collectively walk the length of the UK within the month of March virtually. To raise money for the Marie Curie Solihull Hospice.

story:

This is for a great cause and we would all appreciate your support in helping raise money for Marie Curie. Please follow the link below to donate, and don't forget to like and share with your friends.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
I have decided to join the Step into Spring March challenge for Marie Curie by walking 10,000 steps each day, every day throughout the month

Marie Curie provide vital end of life support to those suffering with a terminal illness and their families, a situation none of us hope to be in but by contributing whatever amount you feel able this will help a great deal to those in need.

I have worked with Marie Curie for 3 years now and every day I see the difference it makes to those whom we support.

Any friends local to me who want to walk with me on a particular day would be most welcome

I am going on a big walk in the Easter holidays, in fancy dress! I would like to raise as much money as possible for front line nurses to be able to keep doing an amazing job looking after people. 

Please sponsor me 😊

Thankyou,

Millie Rose Jeavons x

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
The lifeboat crew at Seahouses Lifeboat Station are mostly volunteers and the station relies on public donations to continue saving lives at sea and keep our beaches safe.  Since the Covid-19 pandemic we have not been able to fundraise via our usual activity so we have set up this page and will be very grateful for any donations.

About us: Seahouses Lifeboat Station was established in 1827 but did not become part of the RNLI until 1852. The new Shannon Class Lifeboat arrived on station on 18 October 2020, and became operational on 31 Dec 2020, is the 14th lifeboat to be stationed at Seahouses, formerly known as North Sunderland. The Station provides rescue cover from Dunstanburgh Castle in the south, to Holy Island to the north, and includes the ever-popular Farne Islands. They are visited by thousands of people a year, aboard passenger boats operating from Seahouses. The area is very popular with visitors, for the wildlife, heritage, and the vast expanse of beaches. The station crew often assist with leisure related callouts, including assisting swimmers, body and kite boarders, yachts, diver related incidents and pleasure craft. People and vehicles cut off by the tide on Holy Island Causeway are another frequent call for the station. This is your chance to help and support our vital work, to save lives at sea.  Thank you so much for your support, we really appreciate it.

story:
In Wales, the RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown. Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives at sea has not stopped. Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds through traditional methods has been limited.

The average lifeboat station in Wales costs £155,000 to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income this year due to the Coronavirus. We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running.

From Flint around the coast to Penarth, we will always be there to keep you and your loved ones safe, on our watch, there will be no preventable deaths on Welsh coasts. Please help us fulfil that mission.

For ideas on how to support or get involved please contact nick_evans@rnli.org.uk

Your donation to this page will help support the running of stations in the Wales as follows:
Aberdovey, Abersoch, Aberystwyth, Angle, Barmouth, Barry Dock, Beaumaris, Borth, Burry Port, Cardigan, Conwy, Criccieth, Fishguard, Flint, Holyhead, Horton and Port Eynon, Little and Broad Haven, Llandudno, Moelfre, New Quay, Penarth, Port Talbot, Porthcawl, Porthdinllaen, Pwllheli, Rhyl, St Davids, Tenby, The Mumbles and Trearddur Bay.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
eventName: RNLI Easter Weekend Virtual Bucket Collection
story:
Because of the pandemic a large number of fundraising activities that our local branch normally undertakes have not been possible; these include Flag Days, Stalls at local events and social evenings.

But RNLI crews have continued to respond 24/7 during these difficult times.

In 2019 alone:

- 8,941 LIFEBOAT LAUNCHES

- 9,379 PEOPLE AIDED

- 220 LIVES SAVED

- 26 PEOPLE AIDED PER DAY, ON AVERAGE

- 143,100 LIVES SAVED IN RNLI HISTORY...AND COUNTING

This Easter weekend we are holding a virtual collection to help ensure this vital service continues.

Please consider making a donation to our appeal, no amount is too small and all donations are eligible for Gift Aid.

Thank you.

About the RNLI

The nearest Lifeboat Station to Cirencester might be over 50 miles away, but you don't have to live by the sea to support the RNLI.

The RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown.

Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives has not stopped.

Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds has been limited.

The coasts of Wales and South West England are popular tourist destinations for millions of holidaymakers from the Midlands and surrounding Counties and we want to keep those coasts a safe place for everyone to visit.

The average lifeboat station in Wales, North West England and Isle of Man costs £159,000 a year to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income due to the Coronavirus.

We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running.

When you and your loved ones visit the coast, we will always be there to keep you safe, on our watch, there will be no preventable deaths on British coasts.

Please help us fulfil that mission by making a donation to our fundraising page, no matter how big or small.

Thank you.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
I am supporting the RNLI lifeboats in the South East this summer by walking from Ramsgate Lifeboat station to Eastbourne lifeboat station. This is around 90miles walking.

RNLI lifeboats in the South East protect hundreds of communities through our 24-hour search and rescue service. They rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. From the stunning Dorset, Sussex and Kent coastlines to the unpredictable tidal Thames, our favourite places in the South east are enjoyed by millions of people from across the country every year. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all 31 South East lifeboat stations is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
pageSummary: My Dad and I are doing a 13 mile walk because we don't know what we would do without them!
pageSummaryWhat: My Dad and I are doing a 13 mile walk
pageSummaryWhy: we don't know what we would do without them!
story:
My Dad, Alvin, and I are taking part in the Cornwall RNLI virtual challenge 2021 to help them raise the money they need for their service to run. In Cornwall, and anywhere near the coast, the RNLI is an additional emergency service, yet it runs completely on donations, with volunteers (including my Dad) working incredibly hard to save lives and keep us all safe. 

We've decided to spend a day walking 13 miles - the distance from Newquay lifeboat station to St Agnes lifeboat station - in order to raise money for the RNLI. 13 is also the number of lifeboat stations on the coast of Cornwall, so a happy extra reason for our 13 miles! Due to the covid pandemic, the RNLI haven't been able to run their usual fundraising events, and so it's a really key time for us to try to support them where we can.

We'll be doing the walk by the end of March - we're aiming for around Saturday the 20th but are going to keep checking in with the weather in order to pick the best day for it. Also please note that we are not doing the actual walk between Newquay and St Agnes - we will be walking in alignment with the current local travel restrictions. 

Thank you for checking out our page - we would love it if you could sponsor us, or even maybe share our page. Thank you again, and stay safe! 

Abbey and Alvin

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
pageSummary: Raising money for David Groves because he was an avid supporter of the charity
pageSummaryWhy: he was an avid supporter of the charity
story:
Written by his lad, James...

At the end of February, I lost my role model, best friend and the most wonderful, kind and caring man I've ever known, David Groves.

David, or Dave as most people knew him by, was an ex Royal Marine and Policeman from West Brom with a heart of gold and genuine love of life who was adored by all who knew him. He was the most practical of men and a beacon of light and hope with the most wonderful soul. His ever-giving, glass half-full attitude made him the most special man and he leaves an irreplaceable void in our lives.

As a private man, this news came as a shock to many of his ex-collegues and friends, but I want to thank you all very much for your messages of condolence and photos during this most difficult time.

Dave was an avid supporter on the RNLI, so this felt like the most appropriate charity to raise money for in his name. You donations and messages are most welcomed.

Best,
James x

___

Just last week, I also signed up for Brighton Marathon 2021 in Dave's memory, running for Cancer Research. Donations again are most welcomed x

https://fundraise.cancerresearchuk.org/page/jamess-giving-page-1275

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
eventName: Malahide Yacht Club St. Patrick's Day RAFFLE
pageSummary: Malahide Yacht Club raising funds because 38th St Patrick's Day Hot whiskey event cancelled.
pageSummaryWhy: 38th St Patrick's Day Hot whiskey event cancelled.
story:
Like to win one of our great prizes from the RNLI St Patrick’s Day Raffle?  And also to know that by taking part, you are continuing the fantastic support of Howth Lifeboat by Malahide Yacht Club.

Tickets €5 each or 6 for €20.

This annual fundraiser in it's 38th year has never been so important to us.  The past year has been tough in so many ways but, like you, we made sacrifices and we made it through.

Although we’re still struggling through the pandemic, there’s
promise of a better spring. The sky is a little lighter, the grass a little
greener. With longer days on the way, more people will be drawn to the water.
Hope of rescue is what they’ll need should they find themselves in trouble. Can we count on you to make sure we’re there for them?

When coronavirus struck, it impacted our fundraising – and we’re
still feeling the effects. We had to cut back. Training courses were cancelled.
Planned lifeboat maintenance was delayed. But still the calls for help kept coming. Wear and tear on kit and equipment carried on. 

Will you keep us ready for when we’re needed most?

Buy a Raffle ticket to bring hope in the darkest storms.

Tickets €5 each or 6 for €20.

Draw on 17th March at 5pm.

Thank you

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
eventName: Sandra Lawson's South West Coastal Path Virtual Challenge
story:
I volunteer as RNLI Fundraising Treasurer for the Congleton Branch  and this Spring,  I am participating in the South West Coast Path Virtual Challenge to cover the equivalent distance of 630miles end to end. I intend to utilise my lockdown daily exercise from home to walk and run the footpaths, lanes and canal towpaths, logging my mileage each day to record  progress along the virtual path around the South West from Minehead to Bournemouth.

All donations from this page go to Congleton RNLI Branch to support our lifeboat stations here in the North West from West Kirby on the Wirrall to Silloth in Cumbria. They really need your help during these very difficult times. Please donate whatever you can which will help me to complete this challenge for the lifesavers. 

The RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown. Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives has not stopped. Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds has been limited. The average lifeboat station in the North West costs £136,000 a year to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income due to the Coronavirus. We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running. All along the North West coast from Silloth to West Kirby, we will always be there to keep you and your loved ones safe, on our watch, there will be no preventable deaths on the North West coast. Please help us fulfil that mission

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
Thank you for visiting our page.

My Dad was a splendid man, loved by family and friends. He sadly passed away on the 25th February, and will be missed enormously.

He hugely admired the RNLI, and was a keen supporter and donator to the cause. Their core values of being trustworthy, courageous, selfless and dependable strongly resonated with him and are very much the standards his own life was lived by, as all that knew him will attest to.

Thank you again for taking the time to visit our page and for any donations in his memory you are able to make.

story:
So Gracie & Adam have decided to make 2021 a year to remember for many reasons, not least their marriage to each other this summer & a major house renovation, but also some challenging and bucket list events to help them raise some money for the RNLI not only because it is a very worthwhile and deserving charity, but most importantly in memory of Gracie's uncle Stuart who sadly passed away on 31.12.2020. 

The RNLI felt like a relevant charity for us given all the additional people flocking to the UK's beaches last summer & most likely this year given the rise of staycations - including the beaches of Cornwall where Adam, and the beaches of North Norfolk where Gracie, spent their summer's growing up, watching the lifeboat going out on training exercises and out to save people when needed it and given the fact their wedding is on the Norfolk coast. In addition to this, Gracie's Uncle had a fond passion for the Lifeboats and model boat building, a hobby also enjoyed by her late Grandad Bill, and memories of her late Grandad Seaside (clue is in the name) who swam in the sea every day from April to October until the end of his life in his 90s. 

Fortunately, none of us have ever required the services of the RNLI, but too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people from getting into trouble in the first place.

So Gracie & Adam welcome any donations you are able to give to not only wish them well, but to encourage them in their events they take on this year - Gracie has a number of events including another half Ironman, to help her build-up to the full Ironman she is due to undertake in Italy in September of this year and her and Adam plan to support Gracie's Dad Bob in his Parkrun efforts once this is available again and then Gracie & Adam will be taking on the Brighton Marathon in September together - they thought it would be a good honeymoon idea ;-) But joking aside, I am sure many of you know why it is a huge deal for Adam & Gracie to cross the finish line together after a little mishap in 2019 - Any supporters to this event are also greatly appreciated - Sunday 12th September 2021. 

They thankyou all for your support and wish you all a fantastic 2021!!

pageSummaryWhy: I want to beat the Zapcat boys going by boat.
story:
The boys from Elite Racing will set off from Plymouth in their Gemini Zapcat heading for Newquay on the opposite coast! This 120 mile trip is expected to take them 3 - 4 hours.


I will set off from the same start point Plymouth heading to the same finish line in Newquay with only my legs for power on this 55 mile trip with only 1 thing in mind- Beat The Boat!

More details and updates will follow but until then PLEASE BE SO KIND TO DONATE FOR THE HEROES OF THE SEA.....THE RNLI! They've had a very busy year keeping you all safe!


Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.Thank you.

eventName: Tunnocks Flotilla The Great Clyde Cruise for RNLI
owner: Tunnocks Flotilla The Great  Clyde Cruise for RNLI
pageSummary: Tunnocks & the Clyde Cruising Club are fundraising because are saving lives at sea 24/7
pageSummaryWhat: Tunnocks & the Clyde Cruising Club are fundraising
story:
Tunnocks Flotilla - The Great Clyde Cruise for RNLI                     

Monday 31st May 2021 - Clyde Cruising Club and other Clyde based Yacht and Boating Clubs & Marinas are combining to bring you a spectacular Flotilla as a fundraiser for the 2021 season, such as has never been seen before.  The biggest mass Flotilla on the Clyde, open to all boats with joining points along the route.         

**Please mention your Boat Name and Marina in the comments when you leave a donation to give us an idea of numbers from each location.                                                                                                                                                                                                                      About RNLI                                           (Royal National Lifeboat Institution): RNLI lifeboats in Scotland protect hundreds of communities with a 24-hour search and rescue service. Our volunteer crews rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. Scotlands unrivalled coasts and waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike, with millions travelling to enjoy them, and work on them each year. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all 46 of the lifeboat stations in Scotland is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. It costs an average of £155k to run a lifeboat station in Scotland but with the implications of Covid-19, we havent been able to fundraise as normal to help keep our lifeboats afloat. Can you help?

pageSummary: Riding LEJOG to raise funds to support the RNLI because I wish to support crews in saving lives at sea.
pageSummaryWhat: Riding LEJOG to raise funds to support the RNLI
pageSummaryWhy: I wish to support crews in saving lives at sea.
story:
On the morning of Friday 2nd July 2021 I will set off and attempt to ride from Lands End to John O’Groats via numerous Life Boat Stations. I have 12 days to accomplish my challenge and will require all the support I can muster in order to succeed.

I have been a crew member at New Brighton RNLI for a few years now and I have been involved in various rescues and training exercises during that time. I recognise the necessity and value of the RNLI and how the organisation places the upmost importance on personal protective equipment and search and rescue units. Without the regular supply of such our launch to aid and assist casualties would be so much more difficult and dangerous.

Last year in 2020 New Brighton RNLI had a record number of call outs. With Covid restrictions set to be relaxed again this Spring and Summer season I envisage another busy year both locally and Nationally. The support of the RNLI is paramount to enable the highly recognised service it provides 24hrs a day, 365 days of the year, covering the British Isles.

The RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown. Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives has not stopped. Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds has been limited.The average lifeboat station in the North West costs £136,000 a year to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income due to the Coronavirus. We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running.All along the North West coast from Silloth to West Kirby, we will always be there to keep you and your loved ones safe, on our watch, there will be no preventable deaths on the North West coast. Please help us fulfil that mission.

pageSummary: I am running a half marathon on my 60th birthday because Looe needs a replacement lifeboat
pageSummaryWhat: I am running a half marathon on my 60th birthday
story:
In 2010 the D-Class Inshore Lifeboat Ollie Naismith was officially named and went on service at Looe. The lifeboat was named after a popular local teenager Ollie Naismith who sadly died in a tragic road traffic accident in 2009. Ollies parents, Maxine and John Naismith spearheaded a fundraising campaign to raise the funds for the lifeboat which has gone on to save many lives in and around Looe including the life of Louis Webber, a young local lad who was of a similar age to Ollie. 

The lifeboat is now coming to the end of its operational life so the team at Looe Lifeboat station are teaming up with the Naismiths and Webber family to launch the Looe Lifeboat Appeal to raise the £78,000 required to provide a replacement lifeboat which will be named the Ollie Naismith II.

Your donation to this community appeal will help to fund this lifeboat which will continue the selfless work of our volunteer lifeboat crew in Looe.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
Lough Swilly RNLI is one of 46 RNLI lifeboat stations around the coast of Ireland. The station was established in 1987 and began operations with an inshore D class inflatable lifeboat (ILB) working within Lough Swilly. By the year 2000 a dedicated lifeboat station was established at Neds Point near Buncrana and an all weather lifeboat (ALB) was added to the station and berthed at Buncrana.
The station now operates and Atlantic 85 ILB and Shannon Class ALB covering all of Lough Swilly and the coastal area west to Tory Island and East to the Foyle and 200 nautical miles out to sea. Over 30 volunteers are on station and engage in all the activities necessary to maintain a 24/7 search and rescue service
saving lives at sea around our coast.

The RNLI is a charity funded and sustained by the generosity of the supporting public  and we are indebted to all of the people in our community and further afield who have supported and continue to support our service over many years.

pageSummary: We are walking 84 miles in one week because of the brave, selfless work they do for everyone.
pageSummaryWhat: We are walking 84 miles in one week
pageSummaryWhy: of the brave, selfless work they do for everyone.
story:
1 hundred and 34km (84 miles)

1 week in the Easter holiday

1 phenomenal charity, the RNLI

1 family: 12 yr old (lazy), 14 yr old (grumpy) & one middle-aged parent (lazy AND grumpy) walking the whole Norfolk coast path from Hunstanton to Hopton-on-sea. 

We are looking forward to (though partially dreading) this epic walk, which we’re sure, will be full of great experiences. Pushing through miles of deep shingle, hiking along beautiful cliffs, marshes and beaches we are proud to be supporting the RNLI, a lifesaving charity that saves hundreds of lives at sea.

For us, walking this route and raising money for the RNLI feels like a way to make a positive difference to our community after a difficult year and think more about our grandad (who was a pilot & lifeboatman in Wells-next-the-sea for many years, but sadly died before we were born) and reconnect with the beautiful Norfolk countryside. We lived in Cromer for many years, our dad lives in Sheringham and we will always feel a great connection to Norfolk and the coast.

Any donation you feel able to make would be much appreciated by this vital institution during any year, but especially this one. The RNLI’s primary source of income (where 94% is from donations) has been seriously impacted this year. All the while though, they have continued to provide 24 hour search & rescue right around the UK and Ireland, throughout the pandemic. Millions of people are likely to stay in the UK this summer and flock to our beautiful beaches where lifeguards and lifeboat crews will be ready: educating, assisting and saving lives. 

The RNLI depends on donations to continue training crews, maintaining boats and equipment, providing lifeguards to 240 of the UK’s busiest beaches, educating and fundraising so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are a lifeline.

Thank you for your support, it all counts.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
pageSummary: I am running the Edinburgh Marathon virtually because they save lives at sea.
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the Edinburgh Marathon virtually
story:
Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.Thank you.

In the past year, reports suggest that the RNLI have been busier than ever.  They are also working hard to help save people from drowning all over the world - I have seen their work first hand in Bangladesh, helping women, children and vulnerable communities learn how to avoid drowning.

I now live near Kinsale where a lifeboat is so important in this coastal area, with family in Falmouth where my mum is laid to rest.  I am raising money for the lifeboat in Kinsale, in Falmouth and for the work of RNLI internationally in their efforts to save lives at sea.

I'll be doing all my training within the 5km limit currently in place - this means lots of hills! Then I'll be running the event on my own - knowing that I'm raising some money for such an important cause will help me round!

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
Every pound and penny raised on this fundraising page will go towards building the new Tower lifeboat station. Their current station is old, cramped and no longer fit for purpose. It lacks proper facilities, and the structure is beyond economical repair, and there is no privacy for vulnerable casualties.

We urgently need your help to fund this purpose-built lifeboat station at Tower to carry on our lifesaving mission. We dont receive government funding so are really counting on your support to help meet the £5M total cost of this project. This is a once-in-a-generation opportunity. Its a chance for you to be part of an enduring London landmark  something really special. Youll be part of our crew and your donation will help save lives in the capital for decades to come.

Thank you for your support

story: I'm taking part in WWF's 100 miles in March challenge this year to help raise money to fight against climate change and global decreasing animal populations. I'm incredibly passionate about the environment and if we can all chip in and do our part to make the world a better place, then we can start to make some progress in helping to heal nature worldwide. That's why I think WWF is such a good cause, because they know what needs to be done to support wildlife and the habitats they live in, and by donating to them, we can all do our part in tackling both the climate crisis and massive nature losses we are facing.

pageSummary: I am Sareena Gallagher, I am raising money because we need to help the world as it is gasping for air
pageSummaryWhat: I am Sareena Gallagher, I am raising money
pageSummaryWhy: we need to help the world as it is gasping for air
story:
The world is “gasping for air” What actions are you willing to take today to help the Planet breathe again?

Together we can create waves, as we have ignored mother natures screams for too long now?

Every second someone is destroying the ecosystem, from poaching black bears to throwing single-use plastic which ends up in the air and seas, and as long as the demand is there the devastation continues.  We are the consumer and we are the problem.

I am thirteen years old and I would like you to help me fundraise for a cause that means a lot to me...those without a voice, the animals that are on the bridge of extinction. 

The funds I raise will be donated to WWF, to help them to repopulate animals close to extinction. I am doing this because I think that WE are destroying the world, their habitat, and WE share this world with the animals too, WE owe it to them to keep them alive. 

I am passionate about the environment, concerned about climate change but feel it is my duty to protect the innocent.

I would be very grateful if you can donate as little as £1 or as much as you can afford, as the more contributions I receive the more animals WE can save.  As a 13-year-old, it's hard to make an impact, but together I/ we stand a chance.

Even if you can't spare a donation please make a life change today: 

 - Walk/ cycle to school/ work.

- Power off electricals before you go to bed (including WiFi).

- Eat less meat, start small maybe cut it out once a week.

- Only buy the essentials, think about food waste!  Think about your pocket!

 - Don't follow fashion trends, no one will know you are wearing last year's wardrobe.

- Don't use wet wipes.  They are handy but deadly.

- Collect rainwater for the garden, use food waste as compost.

- Think about your daily impact and actions on the environment.  Think about how you celebrate.  Cards/ wrapping paper = trees; one-use items end up in the Ocean.

- Think about your carbon footprint.  Grow your own vegetables, buy food that is grown in the UK and is in season.  The supermarkets will follow your trend.  The consumer has so much power...when are YOU going to start driving change?

- Buy sustainable goods (look out for the following labels MSC/ RSPCA)

- Swap to a renewable energy supplier or ethical Bank (e.g Co-operative)

I am one girl, one family...together we are a town/ region/ country/ continent.  Together our actions make a big impact, let us make it a positive one.  Think about the changes YOU were forced to make in lockdown, you think the vaccine is here to save you?  COVID was just a warning of what is to come, DON'T IGNORE THE SIGNs!

Change is happening, but YOU do have the power to change for the better!  Don't leave it to someone else because they are leaving it to YOU!

My family and I will be doing different activities to reach 100 miles by running/ cycling/ swimming and walking (approx. 3-mile  a day) in a month.

Thank you so much for reading, if you donated and especially if you have made a positive change, I want to give a big thank you to you.

Please can you share with your family and friends, spread the message.

story:
Anyone who knows me, knows any sort of physical activity isn’t my strong point😂. I wanted to take part in the 100 miles in March challenge for WWF to take myself out of my comfort zone and support a great cause! As an animal lover WWF is very close to my heart.

I know times are tough right now so  even to donate £1 would mean the world to me!

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit this page in remembrance of Tom Locke.

We lost Tom on 12th February 2021; he passed away peacefully, aged 85, at home surrounded by his family after a brief battle with Cancer.

Mostly known as Tom, but sometimes Ernest or Sonny, he had a big heart and an even bigger smile. Tom was a great Father, Grandfather, Partner, Friend and Neighbour. 

Tom was always the joker, had a sharp wit and a wonderfully caring personality. Tom loved wildlife, whether it was caring for his Fish, his Cat or watching the birds from his Window, this is a cause that was close to his heart so its only right we carry that on in his memory.

The children decided they wanted to do something to help the animals and chose a sponsored litter pick.

Please collect litter from your garden, on walks, on your way to nursery and encourage people to sponsor you. All money will go to our chosen charity WWF (World Wide Fund for Nature).

Help us save the planet ! :)

pageSummary: I am running the London marathon because I would like to help conserve wildlife.
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the London marathon
pageSummaryWhy: I would like to help conserve wildlife.
story:
Hi! Welcome to my just giving page. This is where you get the chance to help keep the lions roaring and the birds chirping, and on the 3rd of October I will be doing just that when I tackle the London Marathon on behalf of WWF. 

Growing up in Africa has given me an appreciation for the natural world that keeps the air we breath fresh, and the things we eat tasty. That's why I've decided that this would be a good way to start giving back to it a little, and I'd like to invite you to help. By donating to my page you can be happy in the fact that you've contributed to keeping your favourite animals safe and happy, whilst also making a lazy uni student get in shape in time for the start line! So it's two for the price of one.

Thank you for taking the time to have a look at my page. Any small bit helps, and please spread the word and share the link! 

Cheers,

Alex.

WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

pageSummary: I'm cycling because wildlife can't raise money for itself.
pageSummaryWhy: wildlife can't raise money for itself.
story:
The pitch

As the world start to kick back into gear the natural world needs our support more than ever. That's why this year I've decided to commit to a cycle ride with a twist.

£1 = 1 mile

Thats right, every £1 donated equals 1 mile I will cycle around Richmond Park for the WWF. In one go* How many miles will I end up doing? That's entirely up to you!

My story

I'm a regular supporter of the WWF, I've done plenty of smaller fundraisers in the past but last year I was supposed to be challenging myself and doing the 100 mile Ride London. Sadly, that got cancelled, y'know, because of the 'rona, but while that event hasn't come back this year I'm desperate to get out there and raise some money for a cause which means so much to me. I also want it to be my biggest challenge yet, but that's up to you, you get to decide exactly how hard this is going to be, so dig deep, push me to breaking point (beyond it even) and help support a great charity that does so much to protect our planet and everything that lives on it. 

*if somehow we get way past 100 miles (which would be amazing) I might have to do some of this on a second day. Because Richmond Park has a closing time.

The WWF blurb that came with the page:
WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
Why WWF?

WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. They are a passionate organisation with strong political influence, global presence and wide-ranging expertise, which is why I am choosing to support them.

Still need convincing?

Initially planned for May, which would have been my peak physical fitness following months of lockdown, the Hackney Half Marathon has now been moved to September - enjoy watching me struggle through, following a summer of undoing all my hard work and a few too many socially distanced pints.

pageSummary: I am running the 2021 London Marathon
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the 2021 London Marathon
story:
Hi everyone,

As you know, running is not my strong point, I find it extremely challenging... but, you will also know I love a challenge! 

I am lucky to have three beautiful nieces and they make me think a lot about the future and what we need to do to help protect our world, for us, for them and for one day, their children! 

Plus the fact that I LOVE animals and want to help protect them in anyway I can... this is why I have chosen to run the marathon for WWF!

WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world and tackling climate change.

Please help me by supporting this cause and sponsoring me, because it will be your encouragement that will help me train day after day and keep me going the full  26.2 miles / 42.16 k ... it might be in tears, but I WILL cross that finish line!

Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive. 

Thank you so much,

Faye x

Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

story:

As a big lover of nature and animals, the aim of WWF in creating an environment where people and wildlife can thrive together is particurly meaningful to me.

pageSummary: I am running the Virtual London Marathon 2021 because It is a charity close to my heart.
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the Virtual London Marathon 2021
pageSummaryWhy: It is a charity close to my heart.
story:
For those of you that might not know me, my name is Lauren.
I would not have put myself down as a runner (ok jogger!) at the end of last
year, nor would my nearest and dearest!

The end of last year I was seriously lacking in any
motivation to get moving (and with a big love of cake!) and I was in need of a
good push, or shall we say an almighty shove to get up and do something about
it! The gentle nudge came in the form of my partner, Tony and just after
Christmas while planning the good old new year’s resolutions we both signed
ourselves up for ‘Couch to 5k’

9 weeks later and with a lot of huffing and puffing we both
successfully completed what we thought was going to be an almighty test of our
mettle. To say it did not test us would be an understatement, but it certainly
ignited my love for running and the thrill of achieving a goal. The niggle that
is wanting to get that little bit further began.

So, in my quest to run that little bit further what better
goal than to sign up for the Virtual London marathon 2021! Which takes place on
the 3rd of October. And what better way to keep the motivation high
than to run for a worthy cause and one that is close to my heart.

This amazing charity is WWF UK, who are working to ensure we
have a healthy and viable planet for our future via their mission to create a
world where people and wildlife can thrive together. Please check out their
website here for more information https://www.wwf.org.uk/

I hope to see you along my journey and any donation to this
worthy cause is much appreciated.

Thank you for supporting me.

Lauren

pageSummary: I am taking part in a 35km trek because I want to help do my bit to combat climate change.
pageSummaryWhat: I am taking part in a 35km trek
pageSummaryWhy: I want to help do my bit to combat climate change.
story:
Thank you for visiting my fundraising page. 

In July, I’ll be taking part in the “Edinburgh 7 Summits” challenge to raise money for WWF. 🐼

In this challenge, I will be taking part in a tough 35km trek that includes 900m of ascent across the course of one day. This trek will take me to the summit of Edinburgh’s 7 hills that surround the city, following historic waterways, forgotten railways, and climbing to the summit of an extinct volcano!

I’ve chosen WWF as my charity as they’re at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. 🌳

Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive. Your support is much appreciated. 💚

Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
pageSummary: Running the Brighton Marathon 2021 because I want to do all I can to look after the planet
pageSummaryWhy: I want to do all I can to look after the planet
story:
WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

We should be doing all that we can to protect all animals and preserve the beautiful planet that we live on. I have been a recreational runner for many years completing a marathon has long been a goal of mine. To have the opportunity to do this and simultaneously raise funds and awareness for WWF would be incredible.

charity.name: WWF-UK
pageSummary: I am running the Manchester Marathon
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the Manchester Marathon
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page!

You'll probably hear me talk about it a lot (a lot A LOT) over the next few months, but I'm running the Manchester Marathon in October, raising money for WWF! I like running a lot, but this is a huge personal challenge for me that I am pretty scared to undertake.

I chose to support WWF because a total of 11,088 sq km of Brazilian rainforest were destroyed from August 2019 to July 2020. Over 1 billion people across the world rely on forest for food, shelter and livelihoods. Forests are also home to over half of the world's land-based species. The Amazon in particular is a vital carbon store that slows down the pace of global warming.

WWF is working with governments and businesses across the world to safeguard against deforestation and tackle the issue - help me to help them!

Thanks :)
