charity.description:
We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
pageSummary: I am running a marathon because I believe in the values of this charity
pageSummaryWhy: I believe in the values of this charity
story:
As the world population grows every year, humans use up more resources and pollute the environment at an alarming rate. Consumption is increasing to unsustainable levels, and it is compounding the problem of global warming (one of the reasons why I don't eat meat - agriculture is one of the biggest contributors). This negatively affects the planet in many ways. I think it is important to help conserve the planet's resources, the oxygen-providing forests and seas, and the humans and animals that live on it (plus I really love pandas and polar bears!).

The WWF is one of the most powerful charities helping create a more sustainable world environment. Economics is a subject I'm really interested in, and the more you read into it the more you start to realize just how important sustainability really is. WWF helps in many ways, for example: 'Working with governments to identify and promote economic and financial system reforms to meet climate, environment and development goals' (See page 'What we do' on WWF website). They even work with businesses and other organisations to promote better corporate social responsibility (CSR) - which is a term you everyone will hear a lot more often in the press/media, and I predict that it's not long until CSR reporting will become part of the statutory accounting reports that businesses have to submit to government agencies (this is currently in the works but at this moment in time difficult to agree on what needs to be reported and how exactly to calculate and quantify the information). 

Another important subject is overfishing. I love eating fish, as do many other people, but the global fishing industry is fishing to unsustainable levels. Overfishing is quickly draining the world's fish stocks, and, again, as the global population grows, consumption increases. If this continues unchecked then eventually fish may become a rare delicacy costing a very high price. A healthy marine habitat helps sustain good oxygen levels, fights global warming and preserves endangered species and plant life, coral reefs etc. The WWF works in collaboration with fisheries, governments and other organisations around the world to prevent overfishing, and finding various solutions to maintain marine life, for example by creating pockets of safe zones where fishing is illegal (in these safe zones marine life can thrive). 

'WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

charity.name: Cool Earth
story:
By joining the Mongol Rally 2021, a charity rally consisting in driving from the United Kingdom to Mongolia in a small vehicle, I'm raising funds to support Cool Earth in halting deforestation and its impact on climate change.
The capital of Mongolia Ulaanbaatar is one of the most polluted cities in the world and last year children have been evacuated due to the toxic air conditions.
This year I'll ride my 1977 Vespa 50 Special a third of the way around the planet combining my passion for motorbike travel to this good cause giving something back to Earth, documenting its beauty to sensitise people to the importance of preserving it for the future of all living things.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

story: A week on a moped through Romania to prove that some lawyers don't wear suits all the time. "It very quickly became clear, Romania is a ridiculously fun place to ride a monkey bike. The whole country is covered in dirt tracks and unpaved roads which make it the ideal place to let rip on a tiny bike. Romania is also home to the Transfagarasan and Transalpina highways, epic slithers of road strewn across the Romanian landscape like a plate of dropped spaghetti. Jeremy Clarkson once proclaimed the Transfagarasan as “The best road in the world”, not that we care, it’s just that he did… And sure, you could grab yourself a multi-million pound supercar and shred up the highways like that curly haired twat, but that wouldn’t give you access to the miles and miles of demanding off-road terrain the Monkey Bike just hates to love - more at https://www.theadventurists.com/adventures/monkey-run-romania/#4"

story:
I'm marking my 50th birthday by running a marathon and I'm hoping some of my friends will form a relay of socially distant running mates  along the way. I'd like to raise some money for Oxfam, who do such valuable work in such a wide range of settings. The pandemic has hit charities very hard, yet the injustices of the world are not just unabated, but exacerbated by Covid.

I know this year has been a struggle for everyone in all sorts of ways, including financial, so I understand that donating might not be possible, but I hope you will consider it if you can.

story:
So, 4 years ago I completed the Trailwalker event walking 100km along the Jurassic Coast along with my sister Rachel and friends Fraser and Josie.  Well, Rachel has convinced me that it's time to head back to the Jurassic Coast again!! This time Rachel and I will be taking on the Ultra Challenge Series event, the Jurassic Coast Challenge, joined by Joni and Maria.

Once more, I'll be raising money for Oxfam. 1 in 9 people around the world goes to bed hungry. The impact of Coronavirus is having a devastating effect around the world. Oxfam is helping in these areas and more to save lives and help lift people out of poverty.  You donation can make a big difference, plus it will help me get through 100km!!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. pageSummary: A team of four, 100K walk in 30 hours because It’s a fantastic charity
pageSummaryWhat: A team of four, 100K walk in 30 hours
story:
100k challenge 

This year we will be taking on the 100 kilometer walk. Hayden, Adam, Ellie and Owen are wanting to complete this walk to challenge ourselves physically and mentally. We are already very active people and  are ready to go up the next level to test our ability and achieve this goal. 

This walk will be taken over 30 hours through day and night no matter the weather. We will be helping to fight poverty and to change peoples lives for the better by raising money through us walking. 

We also have a team support member, Emily Mitchell will be on hand with water, food and encouragement through out. She is also our back up member on standby.
title: 100K Charity Walk
attribution: Hayden Scott, Owen Scott, Ellie Wright, Adam Cook and team support Emily Mitchell

story:
Trailwalker UK supports the incredible work of both Oxfam Great Britain and The Gurkha Welfare Trust.

The 4 of us will be taking on this incredible challenge which will be the hardest one any of us have ever encountered, mentally and physically.

We have signed up to walk 100k in 30 hours across the South Downs on the 25th September and need your help to reach our target of £1400 for the cause.

Please give generously. Your help however big or small will help spur us on to take on this mammoth task.

Love Simon x 2, Tom and Adam and our support team, Gav and Lewis

pageSummary: Trek 100km across the South Downs in under 30hours because Supporting Oxfam's work to help end poverty
pageSummaryWhat: Trek 100km across the South Downs in under 30hours
pageSummaryWhy: Supporting Oxfam's work to help end poverty
story:
We've named our team Instant Regret...which is undoubtedly going to be the emotions we'll be feeling, setting off from the start line.

The aim is to walk 100km through (or up and over?) the South Downs, in under 30hrs.

We are a motley crew, but with one common theme: four Dad's, trying to prove to our wives, that we're still made of tough stuff. 

All of us need to make it through successfully, otherwise we don't complete the event. We're not really too sure why we've picked this event to do, as a few of the videos we've found on YouTube, have not finished! But, we are a determined bunch, and confident we can do it!

Your support, would be great, and will help Oxfam's work towards ending world poverty.

story:
Hello and thank you for visiting our page!

Between the 24th and 26th Sept 2021 we will be taking part in
Trailwalker. Trailwalker being a 100km endurance run/walk/stumble across South Downs that needs to be completed within 30 hours….

Aside from wanting to challenge ourselves, we also want to raise a bit of money for Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust; I’ve included a couple of links below to both charities websites which highlights some of the great work that they do.

About
The Gurkha Welfare Trust : Trailwalker 2021 (oxfamapps.org)

About
Oxfam : Trailwalker 2021 (oxfamapps.org)

If you would like to give a donation no matter how big or small it would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks

Ash, Lottie, Mem & Kieran

pageSummary: I am walking 100km in 30 hours with three mates because I wanted a challenge and it's an amazing cause
pageSummaryWhat: I am walking 100km in 30 hours with three mates
pageSummaryWhy: I wanted a challenge and it's an amazing cause
story: During Lockdown walking has been one of the only things we can consistently do and has been an amazing outlet for me.  Walking is something that I have slowly been getting more into over the last few years and with Corona it has increased to more and more of a hobby and stress reliever.  It occurred to me that it would be great to have a target in Lockdown and to help a great cause while I did it.  I then saw an advert for Trailwalker 2021 and knew I had to take part.  I've managed to drag three of my best mates along with me, and two incredible women to help us get there and to support us on the big day too! If you could help support us in any way then it would be massive, as 100 km's in under 30 hours is not going to be easy. Trailwalker UK supports the incredible work of both Oxfam Great Britain and The Gurkha Welfare Trust.
title: Trailwalker 2021
attribution: The gents that will be doing this with me are Nathan Taylor, James Hodson, and James Crisp. We will then have our amazing support team of Laura Gray and Alison Dowse.
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Trailwalker 2021
ProfileWhat: I am walking 100km in 30 hours with three mates
ProfileWhy: I wanted a challenge and it's an amazing cause

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
I was treated with corrective surgery for a crossed eye (Strabismus, age 4ish) had prescriptions for countless glasses, was gifted gas permeable contact lenses at 14 (Life changing!) chose intraocular lens inserts and laser surgery in my 30's (Even more life changing!) and now I nose about in fussy round trifocal glasses.

All this took me from a -13 prescription in both eyes to something close to 20/20 vision.

I've been been very lucky to receive such excellent eyecare.

So I'm running 10k a day for 100 days straight, raising money for people who can't get the help and support that I got.

If you can join in that would be lovely

Love
Steve x

eventName: Back to School Walk for UNICEF/Yemen
story:
I'm Miranda and I'm 9 years old. I am really happy to be going back to school on 8th March and I want to do something positive for the starving children of Yemen.

Owing to war and conflict, 2 million children in Yemen are acutely malnourished and over 368,000 children under 5 are suffering from severe acute malnutrition and urgently need life-saving food to survive.

My challenge is to walk to school every day for three weeks. Each journey is 1.9 miles so in total I will walk 28 and a half miles. My fundraising target is £275. This money will help UNICEF to provide food, clean water and medical supplies to children and their families.

Any amount of sponsorship, no matter how small, will be very gratefully received. Thank you for your support!

#ChallengeForChildren

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
pageSummary: Sleeping rough because Kids are often forgotten and have no voice
pageSummaryWhy: Kids are often forgotten and have no voice
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our fundraiser for UNICEF.

Having looked at refugees and the difficulties they face, Ben and Lucas were keen to do something to support refugee and migrant children. 


They decided after some consideration that the most relevant challenge they could do was to sleep outside like many refugees do, without even the small safety of a tent. Just a cardboard floor and a tarp over their head.

They spent a night on cardboard on the kitchen floor first to acclimatise. Then on Feb 28th they moved outside.

They slept on cardboard and camping mats under a tarpaulin for the first three nights but when it rained on the third night they got pretty wet, so as it is March and still pretty cold outside their dad added a camping canopy over the top, to make it a bit more waterproof. They have since had two nights of -3° to -4° degrees and the rest between -1° and 10°.

We have explained to them that they are pretty spoilt ‘refugee’ children, as they have a house and school to go to in the day and they have not gone to bed hungry with no idea where breakfast would come from.  
Nonetheless, they have done well, through some pretty cold nights and made it to the end, even on the night they got wet.

Hopefully you will support their chosen charity to help warm them back up 😃

Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Alliance for Better Care has now vaccinated over 100,000 patients across East Surrey and Mid-Sussex. As part of this milestone, we are calling on our team and patients to join us as we fundraise for the Unicef Covid Vaccine Fund.

  Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems. We want to ensure that we support people around the world who don’t have sufficient funds to vaccinate their population or have the infrastructure to arrange a programme like we can in Surrey and Sussex.   We know that if we were to pay for the two doses of vaccine ourselves, it would cost between £5- £20 per person. If you would like to donate the equivalent cost of your vaccine, you can do that through us.
 
£60 transports 4,205 doses of vaccines 
£45 provides cold chain equipment to safely store 500 doses  of vaccine 
£30 gives a full kit to protect a health worker, including  boots, gloves, masks and coveralls
 £20 buys 781 pairs of gloves for health workers 
£10 buys 56 bars of soap to help prevent the spread of the  disease 
£5 provides 1,350 water purification tablets to purify water  in emergency situations

The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.

  Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to our page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

---
Alliance for Better Care is a GP federation that focuses on improving patient care in partnership with its members. We represent GP practices throughout East Surrey, Crawley, Horsham and Mid-Sussex.

We work in partnership with the local GP surgeries to run the following local vaccination sites in Surrey and Sussex in addition to our community roving team and Mobile Vaccination Service.

  • Clair Hall, Haywards Heath
  • Saxonbrook, Crawley
  • Westway Community Centre, Caterham
  • Leacroft Medical Practice, Crawley
  • Woodhatch Place, Reigate
  • Centenary Hall, Smallfield
  • Meridian Hall, East Grinstead

Thank you for helping us to make a difference.

eventName: Cases for Good: Breaking into Consulting
story:
Hello all, welcome to the CfG donation page for UNICEF!

Firstly, we would like to express our appreciation to inState for giving us this opportunity to provide an exclusive workshop specific for state-school students, supporting them in their career path and application journey.

Event Details:

  • Title: Breaking into Consulting
  • Date: 5th March 2021, Friday
  • Time: 1pm UKT


Who we are & What we stand for:

At Cases for Good, we represent charities that share the same vision and values as us, thus providing them financial aid to support the good work they carry out and the impact they provide. 

Currently, we are raising funds for UNICEF who provide humanitarian and developmental aid to children across the globe. This means providing a safe and inclusive environment for every child, improving access to education and reducing child poverty, ultimately shielding every child from any damaging lifelong consequences.

As of today, our very own founders have authored a Guidebook focusing on Market Sizing, which is not only applicable to Consulting interviews but F500 and Big Tech as well. This Guidebook consists of real-life case interview questions and high-level model answers!

To receive a copy of our Market Sizing Guidebook, please make a small financial contribution of £4 or more to UNICEF and email us (contact@casesforgood.co.uk) a screenshot of your donation. Again, all proceeds go to UNICEF so if you are in the position to donate more, please do so. A sincere thank you from all of us as your generous donations will make a huge impact.


- Cases for Good Team

pageSummary: We are campaigning because we want to raise money for their Covax programme
pageSummaryWhy: we want to raise money for their Covax programme
story:
Thanks for visiting our JustGiving page.

We were inspired by the amount of money raised by the Curry Rivel community in the "Twin my Vaccine" Campaign, we want to follow their example.

It's fantastic that our communities in the UK are beginning to be protected against Covid-19. But there are countries who can't afford to vaccinate their people and whose infrastructure may not even include basic refrigeration in places. Unicef have vast experience in delivering vaccines worldwide and so will be major partners in distributing vaccines to the very poorest in the world through their association with the COVAX programme. You can read about it by clicking this link:

https://www.unicef.org/supply/covax-ensuring-global-equitable-access-covid-19-vaccines

Your two doses of vaccine (depending on which kind you had) might be worth between £4 and £30, plus the time and expertise needed to administer it. If you could have afforded to buy it for yourself, please celebrate your vaccination by donating to Unicef.

Unicef have created a video for us to explain more about how they are using your money (you may need to copy and paste):

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=73pSzXnvcGU&feature=youtu.be

Thank you

pageSummary: Colleen MacDonald because We need to remember the poor  Galatians 2:10
pageSummaryWhy: We need to remember the poor  Galatians 2:10
story:
Our UK Vaccination programme is bringing such hope on the horizon. 

I know many of us are aware of our privilege and keen to see out-with the four walls we have been confined to over this last year.  I hope this gives us such an opportunity to love those in less fortunate situations. Let’s celebrate having our vaccine by providing one for someone else! MATCH YOUR VACS :)

Please partner with me in supporting UNICEF as they attempt to bring Covid-19 vaccination to the most vulnerable and poorest in the world. 

To immunise one adult in the UK, a vaccine costs between £4 and £30 for 2 doses, plus the time/ expertise to coordinate and administer the vaccine programme. 

Please donate as you feel able.

With your support, Unicef will deliver 2 billion Covid-19 vaccines for health workers and the most high risk people on our planet.

From buying and transporting supplies through to administering the vaccine, you’ll help deliver history. Your donation will ensure:

  • vaccines are safely stored using cold chain equipment
  • vaccines get to even the most remote places in the world
  • health workers are protected and trained to vaccinate their communities.                 

See the link below to learn more about UNICEF and the COVAX programme. 

https://www.unicef.org/supply/covax-ensuring-global-equitable-access-covid-19-vaccines 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=73pSzXnvcGU&feature=youtu.be

pageSummary: Yoga Unites Us because I wish to show support for the Rohingya people
pageSummaryWhy: I wish to show support for the Rohingya people
story:
I was recently moved by the story of the Rohingya people in Burma/Myanmar and the terrible conditions they are living in as a result of political unrest in Burma. I have family links to Burma, where my grandfather was a Japanese prisoner of war, and was rescued by the Burmese people. A once rich country, but now many living in poverty, I wanted to do something, albeit little, that may help the people of the Rohingya have a better standard of living. As a yogi, I believe we are all equal and should practice being compassionate to ourselves and others.  Acknowledging others, and how we can support each other also helps us in our daily lives, in recognition that we are all connected. 

I will be hosting yoga sessions throughout March to support this charity and asking attendees to donate whatever they can. Thanks in advance, namaste.

pageSummary: Raising money because all deserve an equal chance at being vaccinated
pageSummaryWhy: all deserve an equal chance at being vaccinated
story:
The British are good at a few things: weather small talk, making a brew, and now all things COVID vaccinations, apparently. Equally, we the British say core to our national psyche is our sense of fair play.  

And yet, the COVID-19 vaccine roll out is anything but.  Some lower income countries may not complete their roll outs until the end of 2024, which will mean a lost generation, greater debt burden, and a slower economic recovery.  It could create a vaccine apartheid.  

We can help to not make this happen.   So, if you've received a vaccine please give the gift of two doses - Oxford/Astra Zeneca is ~£6 -  to Unicef to supports Covax's effort to accelerate vaccination programmes around the globe.

For more information about us please visit www.givethemashot.co.uk, and follow us twitter, facebook and instagrame

Please give generously, and thank you! #getonegivetwo

pageSummary: I am raising money because babies in Yemen are dying due to a lack of food☹️.
pageSummaryWhy: babies in Yemen are dying due to a lack of food☹️.
story:
54yrs ago, my Mum was told to choose my name quickly as due to a premature birth, I was likely to die. Mercifully, due to medical intervention, I survived. 

How can it be that today, all these years later, babies in Yemen are dying, simply because they don’t have enough food? This, in a world where billionaires buy Bitcoin and online companies accrue unprecedented profits. 

This is not the way of things; a mother should outlive her child not bury him. She should not witness him gasping to keep an unfed heart beating.

I was incredibly lucky to grow up with an amazing Mum, who sadly will not be with me again this Mother’s Day. In her memory, I will be donating what I would have spent on her to UNICEF,  in the hope that babies in Yemen have hope of the same  ❤️

If, like me, you have lost your Mum, please consider a gift for the Mums of Yemen whose babies were simply born in the wrong place at the wrong time x

story:
Welcome to the the annual EZ Easter Egg raffle!

This year we've gone virtual and you have the chance to win the legendary Hotel Chocolat Ostrich Chocolate Egg, delivered straight to your front door. 

For a chance to win, all you have to do is make a named donation on this page. Each raffle ticket is worth £2, and you can donate whatever value works for you. Please do not donate anonymously if you want to be involved in the raffle as we cannot then allocate you a ticket.

You will receive a confirmation email of your raffle ticket purchase(s) in the next 24-48 hours.

This year we are donating the proceeds to Unicef UK, who have given themselves the mission of delivering 2 billion Covid-19 vaccines for health workers and the most high risk people on our planet. 

Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker, including boots, gloves, masks and coveralls to help make sure that health workers are protected in situations where they may be at risk, while £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves. 

The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.

Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers.
The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.
Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

pageSummary: Running for Ghada because no child should go hungry
story:
Why am I doing this?

It was just a normal evening watching BBC News. The usual stories came up; coronavirus cases, the number of vaccinations, the impact to the economy. 

But then the tone changed. BBC News ran a 6-minute story on the huge humanitarian crisis facing Yemen. They covered Ghada's story, a four-month-old baby from the southern city of Aden, who was brought to hospital for severe acute malnutrition. 

You can watch the video here: https://youtu.be/-LGLlY2ZjWU (3:07 - 5:17)

As I watched, I was so angry and moved to tears. The next morning, I couldn't stop thinking about her and just how unfair it was that this little girl died as a result of being born into civil war and famine. 

While I know that I can't change the world, I can run 50k in her memory and hope my efforts will feed other young children in Yemen, who are in desperate need.

Ghada's story

A little four-month-old baby called Ghada from the southern city of Aden was brought to hospital for severe acute malnutrition. 

Displaced by war, she lay rigid with pain and was running a high fever. The doctor's tried to cool down Ghada with a cold cloth. The test results came back and it wasn't good news.

From there, her health deteriorated so rapidly that they couldn't move her down the hall for a X-ray and was reliant on oxygen to keep her stable. 

And then, just like that, Ghada passed away - she was just four months old!

The facts

According to the UN, Yemen is at risk of the worst famine the world has seen for decades. Malnutrition is at an all-time high with:

  • 2 million children acutely malnourished
  • Over 368,000 children under 5 suffering from severe acute malnutrition and urgently need life-saving food to survive

What you can you do to help

Just £11 could provide life-saving food for a child in Yemen for a week. So, as part of my pledge to raise £2,000, that would feed 182 children in Yemen for a week. 

I'm asking you to pledge £11 or more towards to my fundraising target to Unicef UK.

story:
Dear Friends and Family,

We are immensely happy to be getting married and this union means more with the love and blessings of our friends and family. As we reflect on our lives we realize how lucky and grateful we are for everything we have. Our wedding is not just a celebration of us but a celebration of everyone in our lives. Your presence and well wishes are our biggest gift. We would be extremely touched and grateful if instead of bringing presents you donate for a good cause. We recognize that children of the present will shape our world as the future, their way of seeing life teaches us so many things and to see them suffer is the worst plight for humankind, therefore, the choice of charity for us would be UNICEF. As the native Americans rightly remind us, ‘’ We do not inherit the Earth from our ancestors, we borrow it from our children.’’

If this is not the charity you wish to donate to, please feel free to donate to a charity of your choice - every charity is an effort to better the world. 

Thanking you,  Guill and Yagna

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Funds raised will go to UNICEF UK to support their vision for a world where every child has the same basic right to food, clean water, shelter, healthcare and education.

Donations will be used for national and worldwide programmes and below is an idea of how even the smallest donation helps. So please, even if you can only afford £1, it really is helping to save lives.

11p = a vaccination to protect one child from polio

£3 = a snug blanket to keep a baby warm in a hospital, day-care centre or refugee camp

£5 = enough food to feed a malnourished child for a week

£9.50 = exercise books, pens, pencils, textbooks and other school things to support the education of a child for a whole year

£20 = mosquito nets to protect 10 families from deadly malaria

£65 = a sturdy bike for a child to travel to school so that they don't miss out on their education

£150 = a school-in-a-box containing school equipment for 40 children to continue with their education during an emergency or natural disaster

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
eventName: Selling candles to send the money made to MSF
pageSummary: We are raising money because they save lives
story:
We've decided to sell candles! All the money made (by selling these candles) will be put here, so you can track our progress.

Also, it would be much appreciated if you contribute to the cause.

Why donate?
Over 90% of Doctors without Borders's  global funds come from private supporters like us, allowing them to respond swiftly during an emergency, no matter the religion,race, or views. They treat people in more than 70 countries worldwide and support such as yours ensures that they can respond to epidemics, conflicts, and disasters at a moment’s notice. Among many other things, they are helping with the Covid-19 pandemic where it's needed the most. 

If you want to read more about the organisation go to their website:   https://www.msf.org.uk/doctors-without/borders 

*If you donate here, the money will go straight to Doctors Without Borders.*

Thanks for you help and keep safe!

Angela, Camilla and Abigail

pageSummary: I am doing a 12 hour video game marathon because more countries than ever need help in the pandemic
pageSummaryWhat: I am doing a 12 hour video game marathon
pageSummaryWhy: more countries than ever need help in the pandemic
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page!
I have always wanted to do something big for this charity, even if it only raises a small amount of money, because I have the privilege to live somewhere with free access to medical services that others do not. Now, especially, I have a platform to be able to raise awareness and funds with my Twitch.tv stream!

Did you know in Israel, you're 60 times more likely to have a Covid vaccine than in Palestine? There is an Ebola outbreak in Guinea that is being largely ignored because of the global pandemic. Southern Central African Republic is experiencing unprecedented violence.

These are just some of the 70 countries worldwide that MSF (Doctors without Borders) are trying their very best to provide medical humanitarian assistance to save lives and ease the suffering of people in crisis situations.
---

If you want to come and chat and watch me play some classic 90's Point & Click adventure games for 12 hours, in a marathon setting, then please head on over to https://twitch.tv/mrswiftplays.
I will be playing Monkey Island 1 & 2 and, time permitting, we may start and attempt to finish Curse of Monkey Island as well!

---

Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummary: Raj passed away from Covid, we are fundraising because they're responding to the Covid pandemic globally
pageSummaryWhat: Raj passed away from Covid, we are fundraising
pageSummaryWhy: they're responding to the Covid pandemic globally
story:
Our colleague and friend, Raj Singh, sadly passed away from Covid-19 in January. In remembrance of Raj – honouring his life and helping others at the same time - we have set up a fundraising page for Doctors Without Borders/ Médecins Sans Frontières in their fight against Covid-19 globally. MFS is an international humanitarian medical non-governmental organisation.  

As many of you know Raj was a Solution Architect working in the EMEA Field CTO Team where he focused on Healthcare. Those who had the honour of working with Raj, know we have lost a kind and gentle man who was a great team player. Always helpful, knowledgeable and full of positivity, he will be very much missed by us all at Pure. A few words from his colleagues when remembering Raj:

He loved working at Pure and was a very proud Puritan. 

Raj was someone who lit up a room with his contagious smile and positivity.  

He never made it about ‘him’ - you always felt better after spending time with Raj. 

Raj was a proud father of two extraordinary sons and a devoted son to his mother. 

Raj loved golf, had a thirst for adventure and loved a stiff martini. 

Genuine, The ‘Bees Knees’, True diplomat, Distinguished presence, Loyal friend, Infectious smile

He is gone too soon and will be greatly missed by many.   

Please give what you can to this good cause. The Pure Good Foundation will kindly match our donation up to the value of  $5,000 USD.

charity.name: MALARIA NO MORE UK
story: Every two minutes a child under 5 dies from malaria and yet, it is preventable and treatable. Since 2000 we’ve cut world malaria deaths by 60%, but that progress is in jeopardy and we need to step up efforts. By making a donation, you’ll be helping to protect children and their families from malaria, save lives and create a world where no child suffers needlessly. That means more kids in school, more people in work, less pressure on health services. A future with less poverty and more economic growth.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
From Manchester to Madagascar 

From 15th February, well be walking, running, cycling, rowing and swimming to travel the 5,777 miles between Manchester to Madagascar, all in aid of highlighting WaterAid's work in Antenanarivo, Madagascar.

5,777 miles might take us a while to complete, so we are going to compete in two teams and start at each end - one team in Manchester and one team in Madagascar - and the objective is to meet in the middle by Easter, and see who gets there first!

Well be walking, running, cycling, rowing or even swimming (when allowed!) to help contribute individually and virtually to the 5,777 miles we need to complete together. 

The objective is to improve all our wellbeing, get us all out more in the fresh air and away from our computers, and to raise £5,777 for a truly magnificent cause!

eventName: Walking 1,550 Km in a Month for Charity
pageSummary: We're walking for water so others don't have to because everyone deserves access to clean water.
pageSummaryWhat: We're walking for water so others don't have to
pageSummaryWhy: everyone deserves access to clean water.
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

We're taking up the challenge to walk 4km, 5km, 8km or 12km a day this March so that we can raise funds to help make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. These distances reflect a walk that millions of women and girls around the world have to take each day to get the water they need for their families to survive.

Thank you so much for your support!

Beth, Laura, Chloe, Bolatito, Suganiya, Justin, Beth and Sara.

eventName: ST To Bangladesh and Back Challenge
pageSummary: I am running 200 miles over the next few months because I am raising vital funds for clean water!
pageSummaryWhat: I am running 200 miles over the next few months
pageSummaryWhy: I am raising vital funds for clean water!
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With lockdown restrictions continuing, we’re all looking for ways to keep connected, active and healthy. And while it’s true we can’t travel far, Severn Trent Water has got a sponsorship challenge open to all, that will see us rack up some serious mileage over the Spring and Summer months!

What’s the challenge?

We’re asking everyone to get active and chip in some miles by walking, running or cycling, so that collectively we’ll have covered the distance (c.6k miles) equivalent to get to Bangladesh, in time for WaterAid’s big 40th birthday on 21 July! And if we do really well, maybe even cover the return distance too – all while raising vital funds for our ST WaterAid Bangladesh project in the process.

We've set up a Strava so you can track our progress - https://www.strava.com/clubs/664902

What are we collecting sponsorship for?
I will be helping to raise vital funds towards the series of life-changing initiatives as part of our partnership with WaterAid: bringing clean water supplies and sanitation to over 100,000 people living in the Assusani communities of Bangladesh.

My target is to run 200 miles from the 8th March to the 21st July and to raise £100 for our WaterAid Project!

charity.name: WaterAid
story: Hi my old friends and colleagues, I can’t quite believe it but I will be retiring in the next few weeks - though where have the last 48 years gone? The 13th August 1973, when I first started work it seems only like yesterday but I’ve certainly had a bit of fun since I started in a garage as an Apprentice Panel Beater all those years ago. I realised fairly quickly that repairing dented cars wasn’t going to be the greatest career and so joined Local Government as a Trainee Civil Engineer in 1975 which eventually lead me to joining STW in 2000. And so at Severn Trent after about 13 different managers, 9 different jobs, 4 different bases and whole load of laughs (and really passionate moans) it’s time to improve my golf handicap and do some charity work in the local area. However, after 48 years I have acquired some real quality tat, which I have been advised by Mrs Bywater “won’t be filling up the garage at home” and so for a bit of fun and to mark my retirement I’d like to offer you the chance to take part in a raffle for some of this quality stuff. The proceeds of the Raffle will be equally distributed to three very special charities that are very close to my heart, Prostate Cancer UK, Crohns & Colitis UK and WaterAid. Everyone who contributes will receive a prize, it might be a whole (part used, of course) pack of “post-its” or depending on the number raffle participants a single post-it but everyone will receive something! I know it sounds presumptive but, honestly, I would prefer that anyone who thought they may want to contribute to some B&Q vouchers for my leaving present, would be better off contributing to this raffle and helping to make a difference to the 3 great charities. The chance of winning some outstanding junk as well is an opportunity too good to be missed. I mean, who doesn’t want a second-hand pair of wellies, blunt scissors or a hole punch? I have a very close family member who suffers from Crohns Disease. It is a desperately debilitating illness that is not outwardly obvious but causes considerable pain, discomfort and fatigue. Currently there is no cure, only a cocktail of drugs with many horrible side effects, but still result in frequent hospital visits and operations for long bearing sufferers. Crohns and Colitis UK, like many charities, struggle for funding but still do a brilliant job in supporting those affected and carer families, and importantly funding research. I’m hopeful and confident that a cure will found soon to help those who suffer from this little known, but in fact quite common illness. As some of you may be aware, I was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer in 2016, resulting in a Prostatectomy in early 2017. It’s a cancer that plagues the Bywater family, and was the primary cancer that eventually caused my father to pass away. My two brothers are both affected, and I know many uncles and cousins are similarly affected or have died as a result of this disease. However, this great charity has raised awareness and encouraged men to be tested to spot early signs, and so 4 years later I have the all clear and my brothers are in good places too. I had no signs of illness but following my dad’s death in 1997, my brothers and I made a pact to be tested regularly and it was this monitoring that has spotted our early signs of trouble ahead. Therefore please guys, don’t be proud or macho, get tested (it’s only a simple PFA blood test) and it might save your life! This equally applies to women too, Breast Cancer is the female equivalent of Prostate Cancer and so you too should take testing and monitoring seriously, it may save your life too. The last, but not least, charity is WaterAid. Clean water and good sanitation is something we all take for granted (even though this is what we do for a living) and never really think about as we see it a basic human right, but for many in the world it is not available on demand but a daily chore to fetch and carry filthy disease ridden water for cooking and drinking. You only need to look at the great articles that WaterAid produce to see how a simple tap in a village can make such a huge difference to people’s lives. In 2019, I had the greatest pleasure in working for WaterAid at Glastonbury Festival and have to say it was one of the best working weeks of my life. I hadn’t realised how cleaning loos for Festival goers could be so rewarding but knowing that all the money raised at this brilliant festival goes to just four charities was the icing on a fantastic cake. Therefore, thank you to everyone I have met, worked, agreed, disagreed, annoyed, debated, cajoled or just had a laugh with, I had a great time. Please buy a raffle ticket and obtain some quality rubbish that you can put in the skip, because I couldn’t, just in case I might need it one day!

eventName: Angel guard walks the Antarctic coast
pageSummary: I am walking because everybody deserves safe water.
story: Our clinical washbasins with AI technology will eradicate Healthcare Acquired Infections and provide a safer way to wash your hands. Clean water is important to us, we understand that it can be life saving which is why we've decided to raise money for Water Aid by walking part of the Antarctic coastline! The pipe system of our clinical washbasin unit was designed after inspiration of the feet of the penguin, how they could keep warm in the freezing temperatures of the South Pole which is why we chose the Antarctic. Angel Guard's clinical washbasin units have one main aim – to save millions of lives across the world whilst saving hospitals millions of pounds at the same time. Each year in the UK hundreds of thousands of people become infected in hospitals from the water supplied by taps and showers. Angel Guard prevents this through its unique design (including 100% touch free delivery of water and soap and anti-splash washbasin), materials of construction and use of technology. Each unit contains a variety of different precision sensors monitoring many parameters 24/7 - including flow, hot and cold incoming temperatures, current temperatures and temperature changes in-between flow events. In addition, units have up to 3 bacteria sensors positioned in critical areas such as the hot and cold-water pipes and the tap outlet. Other areas monitored include number of uses, when the unit was last cleaned, has unauthorised liquid been poured down the basin. Each unit then takes the data and risk assesses itself 24/7 based upon the above data and assigns a risk level. If required, a countermeasure will then be deployed including thermal or chemical disinfection. All actions and data are then stored for future reference.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: Access' Manchester to Madagascar 5777 miles for WaterAid
story:
From Manchester to Madagascar 

From 15th February, well be walking, running, cycling, rowing and swimming to travel the 5,777 miles between Manchester to Madagascar, all in aid of highlighting WaterAid's work in Antenanarivo, Madagascar.

5,777 miles might take us a while to complete, so we are going to compete in two teams and start at each end - one team in Manchester and one team in Madagascar - and the objective is to meet in the middle by Easter, and see who gets there first!

Well be walking, running, cycling, rowing or even swimming (when allowed!) to help contribute individually and virtually to the 5,777 miles we need to complete together. 

The objective is to improve all our wellbeing, get us all out more in the fresh air and away from our computers, and to raise £5,777 for a truly magnificent cause!
title: Access agency's Manchester to Madagascar - 5,777 miles for WaterAid!
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Abington Rangers are walking for water so others don't have to. 

We are walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. We are walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

Each Ranger will be walking 4km each day throughout April, they have chosen this charity as they feel it is unfair that girls their age have to do this every day just to get water.

I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.
title: Swaps

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: I'm walking a small distance due to limits of M.E. because Water Aid was my best friend's favourite charity.
pageSummaryWhat: I'm walking a small distance due to limits of M.E.
pageSummaryWhy: Water Aid was my best friend's favourite charity.
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

My part in the March Walk for Water challenge is somewhat diluted! 4k per week, rather than 4,8 or 12k per day is my target as I live with M.E. 

I'm doing this in remembrance of my best friend, who sadly died 4 years ago. Water Aid was her favourite charity - wish me luck!

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
So after a year of doing pretty much nothing but eat biscuits I've taken the unwise decision to wild swim for the first time to the amusement of all who know me.  If you sponsor me it means I can't back down so, by doing so, you will subject me to a weeks and months of regret, horror and self-flagellation.  

If that isn't sufficient motivation you will also help provide clean water, decent toilets and  good hygiene for those that most need it 

Thank you for your support!

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
eventName: Virtual Mount Fuji Run for Yemen
story:
After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water.  

CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.

Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.

CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.

Thank you for reading. For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis
title: Yemen Crisis
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Subtext: Virtual Mount Fuji Run for Yemen
Name: Yemen Crisis

charity.name: CARE International UK
eventName: International Women's Day - Choose to Give Choose to Support
pageSummary: I am raising money because they work tirelessly to raise women up.
pageSummaryWhy: they work tirelessly to raise women up.
story:
With over 70 years of experience, CARE International fights poverty and injustice in the world's most vulnerable places. 

This International Women's Day - I would like to speed fundraise to support the work of Care International is supporting women around the globe.  Please join me.  The plan is to raise at least £1000 in 24 hours.  With your help, I know we can do it!

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
